SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That regulations 7 and 8 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 75 and made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed.

I do not intend to speak for much longer now than I would have earlier on in the proceedings but I do understand the need for senators to participate in this debate. The opposition opposes these regulations because we feel these regulations are not regulations in the interests of good government, nor are they in the interest of allowing full parliamentary scrutiny of a very important area of public policy.

The effect of regulations 233 and 238 would be to remove the list of benefits which are currently covered by assurances of support from the regulations and therefore allow the minister to specify them by notice in the Gazette. In essence, they are the regulations we are concerned about. We are concerned about them because the regulations would remove from parliamentary scrutiny any aspect of ministerial decision making in terms of what is covered under assurances of support.

The remaining regulations for us are innocuous and we do not have any problem with them. But we do have a problem with the principle that says, `We'll take away parliamentary scrutiny from what is covered by an assurance of support and allow a minister at his or her own discretion to make that decision.' We are concerned because the regulations as proposed by the government would allow the government to add any benefit, entitlement or payment to the list of assurances of support at will. That is the crunch of this particular issue. The consequence of allowing the regulations proposed by the government would be, for instance, parliamentary scrutiny of legislation that we are currently debating in respect of the Department of Social Security two‐year waiting period for migrants could very well be undermined.

While the assurances of support do not remove a person's entitlement to social security, they do give the Department of Social Security the power to recover an equivalent amount from the person who signed the assurance. For instance, removing the schedule of benefits from the regulations and allowing the minister to add new benefits by notice in the Gazette will provide the government with an opportunity to get around the difficulties it currently faces in the Senate in getting approval for the Department of Social Security two‐year waiting period.

The minister, for instance, would be able to gazette all those entitlements or benefits covered by assurances and support. He could then proceed to make an assurance of support compulsory for all family reunion therefore effectively achieving much of what is intended by the bill without the need for the bill to pass through the Senate. That is one particular instance of these regulations allowing a minister the capacity to subvert, to avoid, the scrutiny of parliament. It is for that reason that we think these regulations need to be opposed.

Essentially, the principle is: if something is going to be covered, if some benefit is going to be made available, if some benefit is going to be taken back, then there needs to be parliamentary scrutiny of it. Departmental scrutiny of ministerial decision making is not sufficient to cover this situation.

You can go on, for instance, applying your mind to what sort of legislative scrutiny can be avoided if the government has its way and gets these regulations through. For instance, although all refugee and humanitarian categories are currently exempt from the two‐year waiting period legislation, they would be caught in the compulsory assurance provision and the Department of Social Security would also have the power to recover such payments from people coming in here under refugee and humanitarian categories unless there was some further exemptions provided for, and those exemptions have not been provided for.

The basic principle is clear. I anticipate there will be some support for the opposition's position in opposing these regulations. The basic principle is: if a benefit is to be granted, if a benefit is to be withdrawn, if a benefit is to be denied, then let the parliament have some capacity to scrutinise government decision making here. Don't do it through the backdoor. Don't allow the minister in the absence of parliamentary scrutiny to be able to make such decisions.

It is a bad principle that the government wants to follow here. I am sure Senator Short will probably come up with some precedence in respect of this but so be it. In this particular circumstance where we do have some very actively debated issues before the parliament to come in with regulations like this, regulations which would subvert legislation which has been scrutinised by the Senate at the moment, is for us a very bad approach to take. For those reasons, I have moved this motion to disallow regulations Nos 7 and 8 of the migration regulations as contained in statutory rules 1996 No. 75 and made under the Migration Act 1958.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly to this in response, without generating a debate. I do not think either side of the chamber wants that. I want to make some points that are important. I think the opposition's action in relation to this is certainly misguided. Whether it is based on a misunderstanding or whether it is a deliberate exercise to waste the Senate's time and to try to hoodwink senators as to the true meaning of all of this I am not too sure.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion is based upon a misguided view of the opposition that the government has some sort of secret agenda in this area. Frankly, I find it extremely disappointing and hypocritical that someone like Senator Bolkus, who as a former minister for immigration should be expected to have some idea of administration in this area, cannot either understand the issue or alternatively he just wants to stop the Senate from getting on to important issues.

I hope Senator Bolkus will listen to this because, while I, naturally, differed from him on some issues when he was minister for immigration and I was the shadow minister, I think I can say with some pride that the then opposition worked to cooperate in this key area of national policy and administration. I know that the same constructive and responsible approach was taken by the present minister, Mr Ruddock, when he was the shadow minister. We worked to ensure bipartisanship. We understood that in this area the government of the day had a right and responsibility to govern. Whilst we properly acted to scrutinise decisions, our approach was positive. How things seemed to have changed in the last six short months since Labor went into opposition.

The regulations that the opposition has taken such exception to are, quite simply, routine, machinery provisions. They are nothing more and nothing less. They relate to the assurance of support scheme. An assurance of support is a legal commitment by the assurer to repay the Australian government certain welfare benefits if paid to the migrant during the migrant's first two years in Australia. The allowances and benefits in question are established under social security legislation.

As Senator Bolkus should know, from time to time the names of allowances or benefits change or new ones are added and so on. The regulation in question is merely designed to simplify cross‐referencing between social security legislation and the migration legislation scheme—nothing more, nothing less. There is no hidden agenda in this whatsoever. Instead of the migration regulations needing to be amended every time the names of relevant social security allowances change, the regulations provide for the change to be recognised by gazette notice. It is very simple. I cannot see what the opposition's problem is with that idea.

The reality of that situation is that the regulations Labor bequeathed us contained all the relevant social security legislation allowances bar one new one. That was the mature age allowance. The suggestion that the gazettal notice system could be used by stealth to introduce a whole raft of additional allowances for the purpose of the AOS scheme is just nonsense.

The opposition was, after all, in government when the current Migration Act was substantially revised in 1989 and 1994 and when the present migration regulations were made in 1994. When in government, they clearly understood the need from time to time for simplicity in administration. The use of gazette notices is sanctioned in no less than 14 sections of the act and on 68 occasions in the regulations.

We on this side understand the need for the detail to be provided in complex legislation by mechanisms such as gazette notice and I am sure, really, that the opposition does as well. Indeed, the previous government, the now opposition, thought that issues as important as placing limits on the number of visas to be issued in particular classes each year, as important as setting the pass marks for migrants to qualify for entry or even specifying foreign currency levels of application fees, were appropriate for notification by way of gazette notice. We agreed because we understood the need for quick and efficient means of administering complex issues. It seems that the experience of the last 13 years has now been washed away by Labor now in opposition.

The opposition is suggesting that the regulation is some devious way of the government achieving the measures contained in the legislation proposing a two-year waiting period for social security benefits. We, of course, remain committed to that legislation, which was clearly explained before the election. But the reality is that the AOS scheme has been with us for many years. It will need to continue to exist for persons who arrive before the two-year waiting period legislation comes into effect. The need for AOSs, which require an explicit acknowledgment by the assurer of their responsibilities to provide support for the new migrant, will be addressed in due course.

The issue we are dealing with at the moment has nothing to do with policy at all. It is, as I said, a routine, machinery provision. It is one that the previous government, now in opposition, adopted on various occasions in the past. We supported them in the interests of administrative efficiency. It is very regrettable, I must say, that Labor has now changed its attitude on this for what can only be hypocritical, cynical reasons. I really cannot understand any rationale for it. For that reason, we are strongly opposed to the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to outline the reasons for the Australian Democrats support for the disallowance motion that has been moved by the opposition, the motion to disallow regulations 7 and 8 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1996 No. 75. We support the motion for both policy and process reasons. I think Senator Short is wrong to protest that there is no policy rationale behind this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned that these regulations represent an attempt by the minister to remove parliamentary scrutiny of the executive. We are very concerned about that from a process perspective. For Senator Short to claim that in some way the opposition is hoodwinking the Senate with this particular motion is particularly wrong.

Honourable senators may wonder what the fuss is all about. When first looking at these particular regulations they indeed do seem rather innocuous, but I think on a second reading we see that they are a lot more than that. In fact, the minister would have us believe that `it is a routine, machinery provision'. The minister would have us believe that it is in fact a way of bringing in some kind of administrative efficiency—a way, I guess, in future that regulatory amendments may be attended to through ministerial discretion, by the stroke of an administrative pen. But if we look a little closer, we see an attempt by the minister to remove the scrutiny of the Senate with regard to migration regulations and replace it merely with a tabling in the Commonwealth Gazette. I think that is an undesirable and undemocratic state of affairs.

If these regulations had been tabled in the Senate in any portfolio other than the immigration and ethnic affairs portfolio, we would perhaps think that they were innocuous measures, but I think a simple review reveals that this is not the case. In regard to immigration, we have only to look at the policies, not simply the process, of this government since it has come into office to see that what the minister is after is unfettered discretion—unfettered discretion over a broad range of policy areas in his portfolio.

I think an example of this blatant disregard for the rule of law was the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, which has been, of course, a source of attack for the government since it came into office.
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am sorry that Senator Harradine was not here during that debate. I assured the Senate that you would have given everyone a good telling off for that particularly regressive bill. I think this government has made no secret of the fact that it intends to pursue immigration policies which are driven by economic rationalism.
—That's all right—the rest of us did.

—Yes, the rest of us did. That is right, Senator Margetts. While the Democrats fundamentally disagree with the idea that economic rationalism should drive the immigration portfolio, we acknowledge that the minister, Mr Ruddock, has the prerogative to pursue those policies if he so desires. But what the Senate reserves, of course, is the right to scrutinise the way in which migration policies are implemented in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: So clearly any dilution of the checks and balances of the Australian parliament or any attempt to circumvent human rights standards—something we have seen—is not something that the Australian Democrats are about to stand by and endorse. I suggest that there are both clear policy and process considerations before us today and, for that reason, the Australian Democrats do give their support to the disallowance motion before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support this disallowance motion. I do not believe the minister ought to be able to have unfettered rights as far as these regulations are concerned. The parliament has been able to vet such regulations in the past. I am sure that many people in the ethnic community will be hoping that the move by the government to be able to change the rules to make things harder does not succeed. So I agree with the earlier speakers on this side of the chamber and will be supporting Senator Bolkus's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a 10-second statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of time, we will not divide on this issue, but I do want it recorded that we are strongly opposed to the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1996 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Herron:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —At close of play last night I was expressing my deep concern about the ATSIC bill's timing, about the bill's intent and about how changes had been altered yesterday without any consultation with those people who are mightily affected by the changes that are occurring. I was expressing my concern about changing the paradigms of an election. Today, in fact, is the last day for nominations. I believe nominations close at 5 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of the election would be such that—and I am hoping that Minister Herron will clarify this in the committee stage—those people involved in nominating for an election would have had some information given to them about the nature of the council and the organisation for which they were nominating. It would be very interesting for the minister to clarify exactly what information would have been given to people about the nature of the organisation for which they were nominating, whether this information referred to the structure of ATSIC in anticipation of a change in legislation or whether this information related to the structure of the organisation as it exists. In fact, the legislation had not changed at the time the nominations opened.

So, in fact, that would be a very odd situation. I cannot imagine that in an Australian government election the electoral boundaries or the numbers of elected representatives would be changed after people had lodged their nominations. In fact, that would be changing the rules after nominations had closed. I would think that would be a very odd situation.

During the committee stage I will be keen to ask the minister questions such as: if this bill were to be shoved through now in order to change the nature of what people are electing in the ATSIC elections, what will be the cost of an ATSIC election and what might it cost either ATSIC or the Australian public to redo the election if there is a significant challenge to the election?

I mentioned last night as my time ran out that one of the significant changes in this bill was the government's proposal to give the minister power to appoint an administrator. I know that is part of yesterday morning's deal, but I would like to point out very carefully that, if the deal had not been brokered, the bill obviously still would not have gone anywhere and, in fact, we still would not have had an administrator in the bill and in legislation.

BREAK.PARA: So what have we gained? We will have put through a bill which has detrimental impacts, I believe, on self-determination. So what, in fact, has been gained by brokering the deal? That administrator still would not have been in existence because there was no legislation to allow that administrator to be in existence. What have we actually gained?

The appointment of an administrator would mean that the commission would not meet; that the commissioners would not be paid, whether or not they were in any way involved in the matters which led to the appointment of the administrator; and that any delegated powers of the commission may be revoked, thus possibly leading to downstream functions being stopped and so on. That smacked of the most blatant paternalism imaginable. Where else would we find such a power? It is certainly not okay to put such powers in the ATSIC Act because you can easily sell the idea in the community under the accountability mantra.

That is what is happening at the moment. We are turning our back on self‐determination. We still, obviously, have to see what happens in the bill. There was information about what was part of yesterday's deal but, if the deal had not happened, we would not still have had an administrator, because the bill had not gone anywhere. I believe the original bill got taken off the Notice Paper in the House of Representatives. We did not have a bill; we did not have an administrator. Therefore, what have we gained except some other parts where we are moving further away from Aboriginal self‐determination? We are all responsible if we have been part of that.

I must acknowledge that the minister has said he did not envisage these powers of appointing an administrator being used. But I think the whole principle of inserting them in the first place was coercive, threatening and an insult to the organisation. That is why we did not and do not support it.
In summary, we do not support the measures that are introduced by this bill. The Greens (WA) cannot support the bill in its present form. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the views that have been expressed by Senator Margetts on this matter. It really comes down to whether or not we are going to diminish the power of the Aboriginal community, through ATSIC, as a community able to express itself, to find its own way, to make determinations about itself and to move towards self‐determination. There is a clear streak of paternalism in the amendments that are being sought.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not unanimity within the Aboriginal community as we have been led to believe. There is strong community feedback which says that the position Senator Margetts is taking is one that has strong support within the Aboriginal community and I support the position she has taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill was introduced into the Senate on 23 June 1996 and considered on 25 and 26 June 1996, when the Senate amended the bill. The government did not accept those amendments and on 23 June introduced a new bill in identical terms to the original bill in the House of Representatives. That bill was passed by the House on 27 June 1996 and introduced into the Senate on 21 August 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say that—after consultation with the opposition, the Democrats and, I understood, the Greens, totally, and the Independents—substantial agreement was reached on the bill's provisions. The bill as agreed will make ATSIC work better by improving its capacity to provide services to the indigenous community.
I am surprised to hear the statement that there is no unanimity in the Aboriginal community. There never is unanimity in the Aboriginal community.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is there unanimity in the non‐Aboriginal community?
—When is there unanimity in the non‐Aboriginal community? Precisely, Senator Collins. Aboriginal people are no different from non‐Aboriginal people.
—It is an interesting test.
—Yes. And there will never be unanimity, as there is never unanimity—
—There is little unanimity in the Senate. I think you can say that.

—Precisely, Senator Faulkner. To get unanimity in this chamber is almost beyond belief. We do have that in this regard apart from the Greens. The point in relation to changes is that the Greens are changing the goalposts because this bill was introduced. It has always been the government's intention—and it was understood at the election—that that would be the parameter in which the election would be held. The government has not changed its position. The Greens have changed their position but the government has not. There is no implication for the election in that regard. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadowed some questions during my second reading contribution. I think this might be an appropriate time to ask them. I have a couple of general questions. Can the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) advise the chamber exactly what kind of information was provided to those people who were nominating for the current ATSIC elections as to what was the basis of the organisation for which they were nominating. Is there any document available to senators which will provide us with information about exactly what people understood it was they were nominating for?

PARA.BREAK: It would be very hard for anyone to imagine they could pre‐empt the decisions of the Senate. Perhaps the minister could advise me on what basis any information was distributed to prospective nominees for positions in ATSIC elections. Perhaps there was some foreshadowing. I do not know; I have not seen any documentation of any changes. Did people have an understanding that they were nominating for an organisation as it existed, that is, as it was based in legislation, and which has not changed in legislation? Were changes foreshadowed which pre‐empted the Senate's decisions, in which case what changes were foreshadowed? Does this mean that any amendments to that which might have occurred as a result of yesterday's deals were or were not foreshadowed in any foreshad owed changes? On what basis might any foreshadowed changes have been notified?

SPEECH.PARA: What did people think they were nominating for? What did those people nominating for the ATSIC elections believe they were nominating for? What was the basis of that belief? Can the minister provide any documentation to this chamber as to what nominees were advised they were nominating for? What would be the structure and basis of their organisation? It is my belief that the nature of people's nominations may have been affected by what they thought the nature of the organisation was. The size of the groups, the nature of the administration and so on may well affect people's desire or lack of desire to nominate for any organisation.

As I mentioned in my second reading contribution, it would be very odd indeed if, in an Australian election, electoral boundaries or numbers of senators, for instance, were changed after nominations were closed. I would think that would be considered to be very odd and there would be a fair chance that there might be a High Court challenge of some sort if such an election were to take place, there having been changes after nominations were closed.

Can the minister also provide me with information about the expected cost of the current ATSIC elections. Who bears that cost and who might be required to bear that cost if there were a successful High Court challenge based on the actions of the Senate today?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no change. The government signalled its intention when the bill was originally introduced on 25 June. There has been no information distributed because the election date was announced prior to that. No information has been distributed. It is consequent to the passage of this bill. So anybody nominating would be aware of what the parameters were. The cost of the election, as I understand it, will be in the vicinity of $900,000 and that includes research that has gone into it. It is conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission and the cost is borne by ATSIC.
—Can the minister advise me on what date the nominations opened?
—On 27 July.

—So 27 July was the date on which the nominations opened. You are suggesting that for these elections, considering the amount of proposed change, there was no actual information distributed to any prospective nominees, or perhaps electors, to give them an idea of what changes might occur in the organisation for which they are being expected to nominate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government announced its intention. The bill was introduced on 25 June. It was assumed that the bill would be passed. It has never occurred in the past that any information has been distributed until nominations had closed. I am unaware of any; the officers tell me that is the case. So I do not know why any change should occur in this regard.

—On 27 July, had any legislation been passed that would give any proper indication to any member of the community, including the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, that there would be a major change to the organisational structure? At that stage, on 27 July, was there any legislation at all that had changed the structure of the organisation?
—Yes, the House of Representatives passed the legislation.
—Had the legislation passed into law?
—No, obviously not. Clearly it has not. That is why we are here.

—Would it not be a pre-empting of the democratic process of the Senate to provide information about an election on the basis of any decisions the Senate would or would not make in relation to any piece of legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts is saying that, hypothetically, we should put out information. I find the hypothesis that it may or may not pass legislation absurd.

—I am talking about the very idea that you can start an election and then change legislation in a way, as you well know, that is very difficult to control. Viva democracy! The fact that you can start an election and attempt to change the basis of the election and the basis of the organisation whilst the election is in process—that is, once nominations have opened and after nominations have closed—would that not be a rather strange thing to do in a Commonwealth election?
—That is not occurring.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to make one point, which I do not think I have heard the minister say yet. Is it not true that, in response to these concerns from Senator Margetts, you have in fact said that you are taking out of the bill any sections which deal with nomination and qualification for nomination so that she cannot claim, therefore, that there are changes being foisted upon candidates at the last moment unbeknownst to them? Is that not true? Are you not taking that out of the bill?
—Yes, I am. I thank Senator Kernot, but that is pre-empting an amendment that is to come in at a later time.

—Senator Margetts is asking: are people who are in the process of nominating now not finding themselves having new conditions foisted upon them without their knowledge? From what you are saying, I understood that we are not pursuing any of those tightening of qualifications for nomination.
—Yes, I am sorry, there has been a misunderstanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the minister is referring to, section 102, to which I drew his attention yesterday. In fact, that is not what I was asking. Yesterday I expressed my concern that there was in fact a change of criteria for eligibility within the bill which people could well say would be misleading if one were to nominate and after the close of nominations find out that one either was no longer eligible or, perhaps the reverse, did not nominate because they thought someone else was eligible.

SPEECH.PARA: That would mean there are changes to the bill. The bill was announced and it was assumed it would pass in whatever form—and who knows what kind of form would come out of the Senate in the normal democratic process. There are a number of changes to the bill. There are changes that the government is making. There are changes that, obviously, the Greens would like to make. I cannot speak for other parties here; perhaps they are all very happy with everything that is going on. But it is strange to assume in any event that any of these changes will not occur, that there might not be an amendment to the bill which would change eligibility criteria and the nature of the organisation.

No matter what is said here, the nature of the organisation will change once this bill gets royal assent. That was not there. Before the bill got royal assent, it did not exist in legislation. It will exist if the bill goes through to royal assent. It did not exist before that time. So the actual organisation will have changed no matter what was in a bill that did not go anywhere—it went to the House of Representatives and did not go anywhere after the Senate changed it.

The reality is we are dealing with changes to a bill. We are dealing with a process in the Senate. I would like to say that there is never any total guarantee that a government or anybody else has control of the outcome, and we are dealing with an anomalous situation relating to an election for which nominations will close at 5 p.m. today.

I am challenging you on this: is this not a strange and odd thing, are there not changes that were not in legislation yesterday and could this process by which the Senate is meant to debate a bill in fact result in a number of changes whether you have announced them or not? Is that not true, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing that will change is the number of regional councillors.

—The minister just said `the only thing that will change is the number of councillors'. I am not sure that is quite true, Minister. There are other changes too, are there not, Minister? The number of councillors is not the only change in this bill.
—Changes to the structure.
—Are there not changes in the way the organisation is to be run and the role of the minister as well?

—You asked about eligibility. You have shifted the goalposts again. I am saying the only change is the number of councillors in terms of the nominating process—you were talking about 5 o'clock this afternoon. The only thing that will change is the number of regional councillors that will be elected. It is the same eligibility. It is the same process in every other respect.
—I would just like to clarify the amount of money the minister has mentioned. Minister, you quoted $900,000. Are you quite sure this is the cost of the ATSIC election?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of running the election, the information plan shows that research would cost $250,000, campaign advertising would cost $450,000 and publications would cost 200,000. That is a total of $900,000. That is in terms of the regional council elections. The aim of that is to encourage participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the regional council elections either as voters or as candidates. I presume that that is what you are referring to.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, there is the cost to the Australian Electoral Commission of running the election. My understanding is that all up the total of that will be in the vicinity of $4.7 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, I asked what the cost of the election would be; I did not ask for the cost of the propaganda before that. Are you quite sure, Minister—if I can ask the question again—that no information has been distributed to people about the election?
—Yes, that is correct—only what was publicly available in relation to this. I have been advised that no specific information was distributed.
—So what kind of information was publicly available to explain what it was people were voting for—what kind of organisation is voting for what the rules would be?

—Only the information that was available on television and newspapers in relation to the bill that was introduced previously in this chamber and the bill that was passed in the House of Representatives.
—How many councillors was the electorate advised they would be voting for?
—The same number as last time—35. Do you mean councillors or councils?
—Councillors.
—As I said, there was no specific advice.
—You say the same number as last time. Are you talking about the last election?
—You are shifting the goalposts again, with respect. There was no information set out.

—Through you, Mr Chairman, with due respect, the minister just said that the information would have been sent out for about 35 councillors, the same number as last time. How many councillors were there to be elected in the last ATSIC elections?
—The information was sent out on the date of the election and when the elections were on, through the regional councils and when nominations closed.

—I am obviously getting different information. Let us just clarify that. So the only information that was sent out about the election was about the date of the election, when nominations closed and what was the other one?
—And the close of the rolls.
—So there was no information about the number of people to be elected?
—As far as ATSIC is concerned, the answer is no, but the elections are controlled by the Australian Electoral Commission.

—I thank the minister. We can assume from the minister's answer that people, having not been given any information about the size of the organisation and number of councillors, could only assume that the organisation was the same size and number of councillors as they voted for in the previous election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that assumption would not be correct because there was a review conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission. Considerable consultation occurred throughout the whole of the community in that regard and the report was presented to ATSIC with the recommendations that were in this bill. It is not as if it was suddenly foisted upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been considerable debate, discussion and reportage to the board of commissioners in relation to the reduction in number of councillors. It is not something that suddenly came up overnight. It has been in train for 18 months. It is not something that has not been available or debated in the community since that time. It was introduced by the previous government, in fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the minister is saying. There are certainly a number of issues that get debated in the community. I would like to think that community concerns are taken into consideration when such things are discussed. The fact that such things have been discussed is quite different from advising people of any decision that has been made. There cannot have been any decision made, could there, Minister, because it would have had to go through the Senate for a final decision to be made on the number of ATSIC councillors?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is correct. As I say, the report was completed by the Australian Electoral Commission and the recommendations went forward to the previous government and were supported by the previous government and are now supported by the current government. Of course, it does not become law until it passes through the Senate and the House of Representatives.
—Could the minister give us some details of the ATSIC question and answer document prior to the nominations opening?
—What would you like, Senator Margetts?

—We have been absolutely assured that the only information people did get about the election was in relation to the time and date of the election. We were not given any information about the number of councillors. I just wonder if the minister knew about an ATSIC question and answer document in relation to the election?
—If it exists we will get it for you, Senator Margetts.
—With all due respect, if it exists it seems to counteract the previous response saying there was no other information given about the election.

—Senator Margetts is implying that she has information that I do not have and that I am not aware of. I respect the veracity of what she is saying and that she is not filibustering so, if that information exists, I will get it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem here is that it is not Senator Margetts who is moving the goal posts; the information is changing as she questions the minister on this. Firstly, no information had gone out as a prelude to the elections. Now we are finding serially that there were pieces of information sent out to the electorate and, presumably, to potential nominees. What Senator Margetts is also trying to ascertain is whether nominees were told that the elections would be under the existing formula or whether they were going to be under the make‐up and numbers of the council after the legislation, whether there were to be no changes or whether there would be changes. These things do alter the minds of aspirants.

SPEECH.PARA: When you are going to stand for election you like to know what you are standing for. What Senator Margetts is finding out here is, firstly, that the minister does not know what information went to potential nominees, so how could nominees know what they were standing for? What she has not been able to find out is whether those nominees were warned that the positions they were standing for—and, indeed, the terms and conditions of the appointment of the head of that council and whether the appointment was by election or by the minister—might alter. These things are important.

This is an important council. The indigenous community has the right to know what the make‐up of the council is going be. At least it has the right to be fully informed about the changes that are in hand. We began from the position of the minister saying that no information went out and we are now starting to hear—it is important for this committee to know—just what information went out. The problem is, of course, that Senator Margetts seems to have more information on the issue than the minister does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that I am advised that the only information that went out is the date of the election, the closure of the rolls and the closure of nominations. If Senator Margetts has other information, I think it is incumbent upon her to produce it rather than saying hypothetically that there may or may not be something.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to Senator Brown's statements, the nominations have not closed yet. Perhaps he should have used the words `potential nominees', because how are we to know who the nominees are if they have not nominated? Alternatively, if they have nominated, they can always withdraw their nominations. Nominations have not yet closed, Senator Brown. It is another hypothetical.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not seek to interrupt the flow of questions from Senator Margetts, because I understand where she is going on this. In the interim—while she draws breath—in terms of getting to the bottom line, I would like to ask the minister this: if the bill passes, based on the assumption that it does pass, what effect will the bill, once it becomes law, have in respect of the elections? I think it is of concern to everyone in the committee that there is the potential for some legal challenge as a result of any changes made to the basis of the elections. I wonder if the minister could advise the committee—on the assumption that the bill will become law—if that will cause a potential problem in respect of any post‐election legal challenge on the result?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for that question. Senator Margetts raised with me yesterday a matter in relation to paragraph 102. That was under item 28—the disqualification of directors, et cetera, who are consultants. I assured her that if I learned there was any problem with that in respect of the possibility of a legal challenge, then I would be happy to withdraw it. I asked ATSIC to give further consideration to the implications of the amendment proposed to paragraph 102 (1)(c), item 28, of the ATSIC Act. I can confirm that it is possible, in theory, that the election of a person who is a director, has a controlling interest in a body corporate or is a consultant to the commission or TSRA, might be challenged by an unsuccessful candidate. Although the situation is probably unlikely to eventuate, the government is prepared to withdraw the proposed amendment to paragraph 102 of the bill to obviate that. Given that that is withdrawn, ATSIC does not envisage any possible legal challenge in any way if the bill is passed with that amendment removed.
—Thank you.

—I thank the minister for that advice but I must say that it was just one item of the bill that I mentioned yesterday. That was the one that was startlingly obvious to us. If the minister has received legal advice indicating that part of the bill needs to be withdrawn because it may be open to legal challenge if the bill goes through in its present form, which may well invalidate the entire election, has he checked on people's expectations of the total bill to see whether the whole bill could be blown apart and, once again, the elections invalidated? Has the minister received legal advice in relation to the total bill and the implications for possible wide‐open legal challenges?
—The bill is not open to challenge. ATSIC has checked it out and the answer is that it does not see any likelihood of challenge.
—Could I just clarify that? Has the minister received legal advice that the election may not be open to legal challenge as a result of us passing this bill today?

—Any election is open to legal challenge, as you know, Senator Margetts, even in the House of Representatives. That notwithstanding, ATSIC has checked through and does not see any likelihood of legal challenge to anything if the bill is passed.

—There was a question I asked before which I do not think the minister has answered. He may correct me on this. Who would pay the extra $4.7 million, at least, if the election was invalidated and had to be taken again as a result of us rushing through this bill today?
—ATSIC.
—So as a result of the Senate taking an action, ATSIC would have another $4.7 million removed from its funding?
—ATSIC always pays for the election—always has and, presumably, always will.

—The point that Senator Margetts is making here is that the passage of this legislation, on a schedule set by the government, could potentially lead to a legal challenge which would invalidate the election and cause another one. What she is trying to have you clarify is whether the government that is pushing this schedule is going to pick up the tab if that occurs? Will the minister give an assurance to this committee that, if that did occur, the government will pick up the tab and not take another $4.7 million out of ATSIC's pocket?
—The election itself will not be challenged. There may be individual challenges to results of the election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that point needs elaboration. I was just going to say that. Challenges will come from the election of certain councillors—challenges to their election. That has happened in every ATSIC election that I am aware of. I cannot see that the entire election process would be invalidated, although I think you are right to ask that question. I cannot see that the entire election process would be invalidated, because we are dealing with making sure that we do not make that challenge possible because we are not changing any of the nomination criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: If this bill went through on a majority vote of the Senate, in the next month it would be clear to the Electoral Commission how many were being elected in each region, as we know the figure for each regional council. I think the question of $4.7 million having to be found by ATSIC is not the question. The question concerns your assurance that you have had advice that, subject to taking out the tightening up of nomination qualifications, it has all been subject to the usual challenge which individual candidates undertake—that it is not the entire ATSIC election that is being invalidated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot. Yes, that is correct.

—To assist the minister, I have a little more information about the documents that would be of assistance to the Senate. The first document concerns questions and answers in relation to the 1990 regional council election. Page 27 gives regional councillors per ward. I believe that ATSIC has distributed these in their thousands. Could that be confirmed?
—Could you elucidate which election that was, Senator Margetts?

—Sorry, it is called `Questions and answers on the 1996 regional country election'. Page 27 gives the number of regional councillors per ward. I believe that thousands of copies of this document have been distributed.
—I am advised that that may have gone out in an ATSIC document; but it is not available here, nor are we aware of it.

—I would like to just follow up again the business of it not being possible for there to be a challenge to the whole election. We are hearing that the number of councillors may be changed. The power arrangements in the council itself may be altered by an appointment rather than an election of the chair. Is the minister telling the committee that an individual or an entity would not be able to challenge the election itself, that there are no circumstances under which the election could be found to be invalidated? Can he answer that question? I realise it is a difficult one, a matter of opinion, but I would like to have his opinion before the committee. Will the government undertake that this will not be at the expense of ATSIC? It is not ATSIC that is debating the matter here, it is this committee, and the schedule is one of the government's determination?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC budget controls everything, including the election costs. Hypothetically, of course, anything can occur, and that is what you are suggesting: hypothetically, there could be a challenge to the whole election. Hypothetically, I suppose any election can be challenged, even by an individual in the community. As to its validity, of course it is another question. We could go on forever with hypotheticals, but there is no validity in the hypothetical that you are proposing. My advice—ATSIC's legal advice—is that that hypothetical is not a possibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard that said before—that it will not happen—and then it does. It is not hypothetical that this committee is debating this matter. It is not hypothetical that there are changes being made to the numbers of people potentially to be elected. It is not hypothetical that the nomination period closes this afternoon at 5 o'clock under a call to nominees for make-up of councils which may alter by the time they actually get into the council if they are elected. So we are really asking the minister here to take on board responsibility for the fact that the goalposts are being altered, if you like, to use his term. It is not going to be injurious to ATSIC at the end of the day if some challenge is made. That is the nub of it.

SPEECH.PARA: If the government is confident about this, if the minister has done his homework and is sure of his position, you are going to have no trouble with that. What Senator Margetts has a great deal of trouble with, if I am listening to her correctly, is the potential that ATSIC, which has a huge reduction in its funding to contemplate already, might find itself out of pocket to the tune of some millions of dollars if the worst were to happen and a legal challenge were to be mounted. If the government is confident that that is not going to happen let us have the minister say, `If that does happen, we are so sure about it that we have no trouble in saying that we will pick up the tab.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government picks up the whole of the tab of ATSIC—over $1,000 million—so it will be part of that process. In the hypothetical, I am confident that there will be no successful challenge to the election as a whole. You are the one who is saying that hypothetically there could be. I am saying that there will not be. So we differ. The tab will be picked up by ATSIC, as the whole of the tab of ATSIC is picked up by government in any case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand completely the point that Senator Brown has just made and Senator Margetts is making. It is a matter of some substance. ATSIC does indeed have the responsibility, as the minister says, within its budget to pay for the election. The point that Senator Brown, with respect, is making is that this is in a situation where the ATSIC budget has already been seriously reduced. In real terms for the ATSIC commissioners it is not an across-the-board reduction of 11 per cent, as serious as that is, because the government has effectively removed two-thirds of the entire budget of ATSIC from the decision making of its commissioners. I might add in passing that the view of the opposition and my own strong personal view is that it is an iniquitous position to put ATSIC in.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the government's agreement to remove some of the more obnoxious provisions, such as the appointment of an administrator. In real terms, however, ATSIC is but a shell of its former self. The shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs has rightly welcomed the government's agreement to withdraw what we found profoundly objectionable, that is, the appointment of an administrator to replace the entire board. But it should be noted in respect of the point that Senator Brown is making that effectively two-thirds of the organisation's entire budget has already been removed from the purview of the board of ATSIC. Therefore, in terms of real decision making and independence of that decision making, the majority of it has already been removed from the organisation by the government.

The point Senator Brown is making is that therefore ATSIC, the board of commissioners, effectively is only taking decisions in respect of one-third of its budget, and that is having to do the dirty work of handing out cuts of in excess of 30 per cent across the board to those areas where it is still left with any discretion.

If the minister is wrong, and if the advice is wrong, and if through no fault of the commission itself additional expense is required as a direct result of the passage of this legislation—I think this is the point that Senator Brown is making—in colloquial terms, rather than parliamentary terms, if you like, do you think as minister for Aboriginal affairs that it would be fair in an already highly restricted budget to impose a potential significant cost on ATSIC, if the fault was ours collectively rather than theirs?

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Collins's sentiments. Should that hypothetical situation occur, of course we will address it.

—I am pleased to hear some movement here on the concern that Senator Margetts has raised. Does movement mean that the government will underwrite ATSIC if it finds itself potentially paying for legal action as a result of this legislation and its impact on elections?
—I am saying that we will cross the bridge when we come to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —To add to the implications as to why there might be a potential for the election to be challenged, I would like to mention the second document—the ATSIC Regional Council elections guide . Pages 22 and 23 list the regional wards and vacancies. Is the minister aware of this document?
—No.

—Perhaps during the next few minutes somebody will be able to find out exactly what people were advised in the Australian Electoral Commission's electoral guide as to the number of regional wards and vacancies and as to the distribution of this document.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Margetts is doing, and she has an absolute right to do so. But I wonder whether I could throw myself, as a simple member of this committee, at her mercy and ask whether she could do the committee an enormous favour and cut to the chase. Senator Margetts has documents which none of the rest of us are in possession of.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Margetts is clearly making a point, and it is one that I find tantalising. I do not want to be shadow‐boxing any more on this. It would be of enormous assistance, Senator Margetts, if you could tell the committee directly—I understand the point you are making—what parts of the written advice that have already been circulated to Aboriginal people who may participate in this election would cause, in your view, a potential problem should this bill be passed by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was only last night that the story began to unfold. It was only yesterday that I found out that the nominations were closing. It was only yesterday that I made known the initial questions to the minister about section 120 and got an unsatisfactory answer.

SPEECH.PARA: With all due respect, I have to say to Senator Bob Collins that I am seeking information and that whilst I am speaking, and whilst the minister was giving assurances, I am getting messages on the telephone that these documents exist. I am not shadow‐boxing; I am seeking information. We are receiving assurances which it seems cannot be backed up. As we are dealing with things that affect an election which is going on now, I would have thought that, as I am seeking this information, there would be advisers who have some knowledge of the information that was sent out about the nature of this election, which relates to this legislation.

I am seeking this information and finding from the community that these documents exist. So I am not playing games. In fact, I am trying to seek information and have received assurances—a phone call saying that this is not true. I first asked the question about the cost of the election. A phone call came through saying that that is not true. So I ask again. That is what I am doing. I am genuinely seeking information. I am really appalled at the process that is happening here.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I did not make myself clear enough to Senator Margetts. I apologise and will try again. Information has been sought from the government as to what had been distributed prior to the election, and questions were asked by you, the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot), me and others about whether any of that would be invalidated by the passage of this legislation.

INTERJECT.PARA: The point I am making is this: rightly or wrongly, the government has replied to that question and has said no. As a member of the committee, I am genuinely interested to know whether you have information. You referred to documents; I am sorry if I assumed that you had them. The fact is that they have provided it. They have said that they are satisfied that nothing that has been circulated will cause a problem in terms of invalidating any result should this bill be passed. I am asking you whether you have information that contests that view.

Let me tell you that this is a genuine position that I am putting to this committee. For the sake of ATSIC, rather than the government, and the orderly conduct of its elections we are prepared to be supportive of some of these proposals. Indeed, as the minister knows, and as everyone knows, a compromise has been reached on some of these things.

I am concerned and I know that Senator Kernot is concerned—we are all concerned, and we have expressed those concerns to the minister and, indeed, to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill)—that we are relying on the advice that this will not cause a problem. We have been told it will not. I am asking you this: do you have any specific information about the material that has been circulated that in your view does cause a potential problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an intriguing proposition.
—Commonsense, I would have thought.
—That is how it works here.

—I do not need advice on how it works here, Senator Kernot. I am just using commonsense, if you would let me finish. It is the minister who ought to be providing this information. Earlier in this committee, in response to questioning from Senator Margetts, the minister said that no information had gone out. He was wrong. We now find that information had gone out.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts is saying that the community are informing her, through her office—from goodness knows where in Australia; presumably because they are listening to the broadcast of these proceedings—that there is information available. I do not want to say that the minister has misled the committee, but that is how it sounded to me when he said at the outset that there was not information. We now know that there is.

BREAK.PARA: Let the minister provide this committee with all the information that has gone out as a prelude to this election to inform nominees, so that we do exactly know and so that this committee is properly informed in deliberating on this matter. That is the government's responsibility. That is the minister's responsibility. At the moment we are dependent on the information that Senator Margetts is getting, but that is not the proper way for this committee to be functioning.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clarify my interjection. Yes, it is the responsibility of the minister to provide the information, but in the committee of the whole we have a practice which means that we are able to ask each other to explain the point of what it is that we are pursuing. That is the way the committee of the whole operates. While you are right to say that the minister should provide information, Senator Collins is equally right, under our rules, to ask Senator Margetts if she could clarify what it is that she is getting to. That is the point I was making in my interjection.
—Cut to the chase, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, indeed. The point of my line of questioning was to find out whether in fact the statement by the minister is correct, that people would have known what the basis of the election was because there had been a discussion, an inquiry and papers put out about potential changes. I am trying to get to the veracity of whether people would have known what the basis of this election was and what the official information is actually telling them about this election.

PARA.BREAK: We have nothing, except the minister saying, `They would have known because we had an inquiry.' We have inquiries about many things but I can tell you that until a decision or legislation has been passed there is no certainty that that is the decision. The minister is suggesting that groups—candidates, electors and interested people—would have known what the election was about and what the structure and basis of the organisa tion was about because there had been a discussion about it.

SPEECH.PARA: What I was trying to find out was the gap between what that discussion was all about and what any official information is that has been sent out to communities. If this information can be made available during the course of the committee, I will be happy to table it or I would be very happy if the minister could table it. I have given the page numbers. Perhaps through the parliamentary library or some way we can put this information on the floor to be tabled or to be put in Hansard.

It is important. If you say that no information has been given, if you say that people would have known, then it is important to see whether there is a gap between the official information that has been given about the nature of this election and what will be the outcome as a result of this election passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can elucidate the problem and I do not question the bona fides of Senator Margetts. She is quoting from an Australian Electoral Commission information booklet. I can only speak on behalf of ATSIC. I am not responsible for the Australian Electoral Commission that conducts the election.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of information that has been distributed, I have checked with ATSIC and ATSIC said that the only information they have put out is a pamphlet saying: `Why participate in the election?' There is nothing in relation to detail of the election. It appears we are talking about two separate documents. One is the Australian Electoral Commission—is that correct? That has been distributed by the Australian Electoral Commission.

Secondly, ATSIC, through its regional offices and through its councils and presumably through radio as well, has spoken about the election and the timing thereof. I understand there is a booklet on its way from ATSIC which deals with the how and when questions. So there are two separate items that you are referring to, I presume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to revisit the question of the whole election being invalidated and go through a check list of what we know. We know that circumstances surrounding nominations are not changing. That process is not changing. We know that nominations are closing and that the rolls are closing in accordance with what everyone has been told.
—Yes, that's correct.
—That has not changed. We know the period of the election. We know that the election is going to be on 12 October. That is not changing.
—That's correct.
—We know that the number of commissioners is going to be 19. That is not changing.
—We haven't passed the bill yet. We don't know that.
—This is in the existing bill. All of this is in the existing bill?
—Correct.
—The existing bill. Where? What bill?
—The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act updated—
—This has not been passed yet.
—This is the 1 June 1995 version, not the new bill.
—Which hasn't passed.

—It has. This is the existing act I am talking about. So nothing has changed in nominations, opening and closure of rolls, the period of election, the date of election, or the number of commissioners.
—Number of councillors?

—I am getting to that next. What the new bill is proposing to do is not implement what was about to happen, which was the election of the chair of ATSIC, and maintain the appointment. So that is a change. When we get down to the other provisions of this existing bill, when we get down to the number of regional councils, the number of regional councillors and wards, that is where I think we need some clarification. Division 4—Regional Council elections, clause 100 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Regional Council elections shall be conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission in accordance with:
(a) the provisions of this Act; and
(b) the Regional Council election rules in force at the beginning of the election period.
Then it says:
Rules may divide regions into wards and no more than five wards in each region.

So what we are looking at is: have people been disadvantaged in any way to this point in the process? In the next month to come, if the rules, the numbers of regional councillors, are clarified by the Australian Electoral Commission, is this likely to invalidate the election in any way? That to me is the only issue from that entire list over which there is a question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: HERRON

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I have received is that it won't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There certainly may be problems with these amendments from the Greens' point of view. Amendments 2 and 3 are the ministerial appointments of councillors to stop some regions missing out if numbers are reduced. There is nothing in the bill which actually indicates what the process will be. The minister may make some statements, I guess, about how this process would take place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens (WA) certainly have a severe problem with amendments 2 and 3, which allow the minister to appoint councillors. If there is nothing in the bill which sets out the basis of this appointment then, theoretically, the minister can decide how that will happen. Whether or not he chooses to do it by the next on the list or any other means certainly leaves a rather odd situation in terms of self-determination, if that is in indeed what ATSIC is meant to be about. So we would strongly oppose that.

Amendment 1 and schedule 3 bring in elections for the chair after 1999. If the status quo remains without any amendments, these current elections will have an elected chair. People will note that my amendment No. 7 would bring elections up in 1996. By putting all these amendments together, it would make it a little difficult, I think. I could still put my amendment later, but it would make it difficult for me to run my amendment No. 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It might clarify it if I state that my understanding is that the minister can appoint additional regional councillors only after consulting the ATSIC board. The mechanism to be used will be that the minister will consider increasing the number of regional councillors at the request of the ATSIC board.
—I thank the minister. Who are the people who would normally select regional councillors? Is it the ATSIC board?
—It is up to individual nominees, the electors of those regional councils.

—I understand, then, that the electors are being replaced by the minister, who, in consultation with the board—no binding consultation, as mentioned here—is able to make an appointment, or appointments of any number, if the minister so wants.
—Only at the request of the board of ATSIC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It just might be useful to explain why this amendment has eventuated. When we debated this last time and we talked about a reduction in the number of regional councillors, the recommendation to do that came from a review conducted by ATSIC. So we are not bypassing ATSIC consideration of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Senate committee hearing, several regional councillors said, `We understand why we want this to happen, but it has a problem in that, because of the distribution of population in each ward, there will be some pockets of communities who are small in number who may be unrepresented.' At the time, as I recall, the Senate said, `We can appreciate the principle of the reduction in number and we take ATSIC's advice on board, but we are still uneasy about this lack of representation in certain areas.' This proposal is meant to address that.

What I think is missing from it is the finer detail, which would be: are you going to look at the list of nominees, those who put themselves up for election to the council, as a starting point, or are you going to take the advice of the regional council of that whole area, or are you going to simply ask the board of commissioners to talk to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that we will seek the advice of the regional councils. I presume they would look at who were unsuccessful on the ballot at that time.
—And represented the community that was unrepresented.
—Yes, but it will be up to the regional councils themselves to recommend.

—I believe the wording of the bill is `the minister is of the opinion'. So, in fact, the bill leaves it open to the minister to ignore advice if he so deems. In fact, the bill in its current wording would allow the minister to make his own appointments if he so chooses to ignore the opinions of any other bodies, including ATSIC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the opposition will be moving an amendment, which should be before you, which clarifies the mechanism. That amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A report to the minister under subsection (3) in respect of the first Regional Council elections conducted after 1 July 1996 must include an examination of ways in which the representation of distinct community groups on Regional Councils could be accommodated.

We will be supporting that amendment, which covers the matter that you referred to. I do not believe I have the discretion. The mechanism, as I said, will be that it will be at the request of the ATSIC board which, in turn, will come from the regional councils to the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did actually read out that part of the bill which says `the minister is of the opinion'. It does not actually say that the minister is required to take the advice of anybody. It does in fact say `the minister is of the opinion'. Is that not true, minister?
—Yes, that is correct.

—Can the minister give an indication of what level of concern communities have shown in relation to the reduction in the number of regional councillors and which areas may in fact lose representation as a result in the reduction of the number of regional councillors?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Those matters were considered by the review that was conducted. After the election there will be another, subsequent review. It is under continual review. That is in the act. There again, there was concern expressed at the previous review in that regard. All those considerations were taken into account when the recommendations came forward from the board of review.
—I was wondering at what time I am able to put my amendment No. 7. Is this the appropriate time?
