SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (lines 16 to 18), omit the item.

This is the item reducing the number of councillors. As I mentioned in my speech, I think this has been arbitrary. There is a lot of concern in the community as to what it means in terms of community representation, the future distribution of services and decision making on an ongoing basis. Therefore, we oppose the reduction of the number of councillors.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Schedule 1. page 3, (after line 18), after item 3, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:
(4A) Determinations under subsection (1) are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment was originally numbered 3A, not 3B. The numbering of this amendment was changed from 3A to 3B because a new 3A has already been inserted by way of previous government amendments.

The reason for my moving this amendment is that there is power under this bill for the minister to give general directions to the commission. I do understand there are some restrictions on that, but I believe that we should have some ability for the community, most particularly the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, to have some input when such decisions are made. That input should mean that such decisions could be disallowable, that those concerns can be brought to the parliament via the Senate by way of a disallowable instrument.

I think it is a very dangerous thing if we, via this legislation, give the minister power to give general directions which do not have that accountability back to the community that they are meant to be representing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate that the Democrats support this amendment. I think the practice, the power to just issue general directions without any debate, is unacceptable. I think the general procedure of having this as a disallowable instrument is a really good way for us to say to the minister, `Why is it necessary to do this?'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting this particular provision. I say, just briefly, that I actually understand fully the reasons why Senator Kernot and Senator Margetts are supporting this proposition. It is just that I have an heretical view, I guess, in terms of an across-the-board position: I probably have as little confidence in the Senate being as rational a director of ATSIC as I have in the minister being a rational director of ATSIC. I think it is probably in line—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It would give us all a say. But in general terms—and I would `fess up immediately that the difference in approach is caused by the fact that I, having been in government and having been a minister for seven years, think ministers should be properly accountable—knowing the processes of the Senate and knowing the extraordinary reasons why these directions should be issued in the first place, we are not minded to support this particular amendment although we have great sympathy with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that we have great sympathy with it—this is a matter of public record, but it should be put down again on the public record—is that I profoundly and strongly believe the ministerial direction which was issued for the first time earlier this year was iniquitous, was absolutely without justification. I also believe, rightly or wrongly, that the minister was nothing but a pawn in this arrangement.

I believe that he himself did not take to cabinet such a proposition, in terms of freezing the entire disbursements of ATSIC causing the most horrendous repercussions in Aboriginal communities. He then had the ignominious task—it was ignominious; and, having sat over there, I know just exactly how ignominious it must have been—to be forced to come into the Senate and reissue an amended direction effectively negating the effect of his first direction because of the mess that that had caused.

Senator Margetts, the reason I raise that point is that without the direction—this is why we will not be supporting it—being made a disallowable instrument, I thought the Senate on that occasion, and the opportunities it gave us to raise the problems caused by minister's directions, did make him properly accountable at the end of the day and it did it in a fairly expeditious manner. The evidence is all there in the Senate Hansard. The minister was forced at the end of the day to reissue his direction.

In conclusion, I want to make a point about this matter that I will make again in this debate, without apology, before we leave here today—that is, why this action was outrageous. I am not letting the minister off the hook. He is here to represent the government and he acknowledges that. It was a government action that was taken. I know who beat him up in cabinet and who took it. It is the government that I have a problem with. I know that he was simply a pawn, but it was swept aside in this particular matter.
This document, which I am holding, is the Australian National Audit Office report on the diesel fuel rebate scheme. This is a very fresh document. See the nice shiny cover!

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good comparison.

—It is the appropriate comparison, I think, Senator Kernot, because the amounts of public money involved are very similar. This report was tabled in the parliament only a very short time ago. It makes very interesting reading. As the former primary industries minister, it was a scheme that I had some passing interest in although it was administered by the Customs Service. This Audit Office report reveals that this scheme—as supportable, in my opinion, as it is—is losing, conservatively, something like $40 million a year in rip-offs and rorts. The report itself makes the point that this is a conservative figure.

SPEECH.PARA: The government itself has placed a far higher figure on it. They expect to get savings—as they are referred to—of $400 million from this scheme over the next four years in fixing the rorts. That is in the budget papers. The government clearly agrees with the audit office that the $30 million to $40 million figure is indeed a conservative figure.

We had a ministerial direction issued to ATSIC freezing all of its disbursements—all of them. Every single organisation in Australia funded by ATSIC was considered guilty until proven innocent on the basis—Senator Kernot would recall it only too well—and on the minister's own admissions to a Senate committee, that the government had got spooked by some nasty publicity on television and by the statements made in public by people like Pauline Hanson. Have a look at the Hansard of the committee in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at her maiden speech.

—Senator Brown, I commended you yesterday on the speech you delivered. I did not agree with all of it; I did not agree with lots of it, but I agreed with a great deal of it. I made the point to you yesterday that the reason I did not immediately come into the chamber to listen to your first speech was not through any lack of courtesy; it was because I was fascinated by what was happening in the other chamber as well. While you were delivering your first speech, Pauline Hanson was delivering hers in the Reps and I was channel hopping in my office, and I freely confess it. It was an extraordinary comparison. There is room for all of us in here. There are racists, rednecks and people who hate Asians and blacks in Australia and I suppose they deserve to be represented in parliament, and they are.
—They don't all live in Oxley, though.

—No, they don't. Unfortunately, they do not. I was amazed to hear a member of this parliament advocating that we go back to the White Australia policy—which is what she said—and nominating the countries from whom we do not want people in Australia today, but it is all in the Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: The minister admitted to a Senate committee that part of the reason for the issuing of that direction—freezing ATSIC's funds—was because of statements made by people like Pauline Hanson and the publicity on the Sunday program about the Redfern Legal Aid Service, which I can tell you I will be happy to come down on like a tonne of bricks at the appropriate opportunity in the Senate as much as anyone will be. That was the basis for freezing the entire funds of ATSIC, an Aboriginal organisation. This audit report identifies $40 million in rorts from the scheme. The government itself has put the figure in the budget papers at $100 million that they expect to get back in eliminating those rorts.

Would anyone have seriously suggested, on the basis of this report which was tabled in the Senate recently, that the minister responsible for customs would have issued a direction to the administrators of this scheme freezing every single disbursement to every Australian farmer and miner—the recipients of this benefit—as a result of these rorts which far outweigh anything that ATSIC, on its worst day, has ever been accused of doing? Of course, they did not. As I said publicly at the time, it would have been absurd of anyone to have suggested that they should have done so.

In cabinet that day—and I have no doubt that it was not in the submission which the minister took to cabinet—the government took this outrageous decision which caused the most horrendous dislocation to employment programs, to the provision of water supplies and sewage services in tiny Aboriginal communities all across Australia with horrendous health problems and forced the minister, at the end of the day, into the ignominious position in the Senate of rescinding his original direction and issuing a new one which completely negated the first.

You may object, Minister, but I do not think it is an invalid comparison to make in the chamber, and I might give it a passing reference again in the appropriate amendment that is to be moved by me shortly. The way in which miners and primary producers were treated by this government, and the way in which the Aboriginal people of Australia were treated by this government on exactly the same grounds, stands in stark contrast.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all the more reason why Senator Bob Collins should vote for this amendment.
—We forced him to change it.

—Yes, but it is not a matter of who is more rational—the Senate or the minister—in relation to ATSIC, although I take your point. One does wonder from time to time with the debates we have had in here over the past three or four years. The way we held the minister to account last time was via a censure motion. I think this is a better mechanism for providing for permanent debate. You cannot always rely on the suspension of standing orders to bring on a censure debate in order to make the points that we are able to make in debate. We saw what happened as a result of the issuing of that general direction. It came out of the blue. That is why I think that Senator Margetts's amendment is a safeguard to say, `Don't let it happen that way again. Yes, they will go ahead and issue general directions, perhaps, but we will have an automatic right to debate them in the Senate.' That, I think, is the strength of this amendment.

—I would like to echo the comments of Senator Kernot. It is not necessary for us to have a say. We do have a say but, as Senator Bob Collins says, sometimes that say is effective and sometimes, when it is a matter of censure, it is not. We only have to see how often debates in relation to previous ministers were ignored—
—Badges of honour.

—They were, as Senator Kernot mentions, worn as badges of honour. They were ignored. Some people say those mechanisms have no guarantees of working. If there were an automatic ability for a debate on disallowance, then the Senate would be able to vote, not for us to have a say but for time to enable communities which would be affected by what might be arbitrary ministerial decisions based on political expediency—and we have seen some evidence of that—to have a say through their elected representatives. We have seen scapegoating to a horrible extent as a result of the budget and pre‐budget decisions. Were scapegoating to occur via ministerial edict, then that mechanism would be necessary to allow the people most affected to have a say. That is the importance of this measure and that is why I was hoping the Labor Party would support it. Obviously, it was a vain hope.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Schedule 1, item 48, page 26 (line 23), omit "Imprisonment for 1 year", substitute "50 penalty units".
4. Schedule 1, item 50, page 27 (line 25), omit "Imprisonment for 5 years", substitute "200 penalty units".
5. Schedule 1, item 52, page 28 (lines 2 to 3), omit "imprisonment for not more than 6 months", substitute "a fine not exceeding 25 penalty units".
6. Schedule 1, item 55, page 28 (line 14), omit "Imprisonment for 6 months", substitute "25 penalty units".
7. Schedule 1, item 55, page 28 (line 18), omit "Imprisonment for 6 months", substitute "25 penalty points".

The amendments all relate to removing references to prison penalties within the act and substitution of the appropriate penalty units. These are the same amendments moved by my former colleague Christabel Chamarette in relation to this same bill in June this year. There is no diminution in the range of discretion that is given, but there is a principle being applied. As many senators would be well aware, this is consistent with the campaign that my former colleague con ducted in relation to social security and other bills.

The reason that I am moving this amendment is to apply the principle that prison should be a penalty of last resort and that our commitment to that principle should not be simply nominal. In particular, I believe we have a case in point that the offences here are serious ones. There is no question about that. The question as to what is the most appropriate penalty can be answered with almost complete certainty that prison should not be used as a first resort, which is what is implied, and that has been stated in this way in the act.

It should be up to the court to determine the appropriate penalties. To have penalty units means there is a range of sanctions and penalties the court can apply. We should be particularly concerned about this when discussing ATSIC bills because recommendation No. 92 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody strongly urges that imprisonment be applied only as a penalty of last resort.

I believe we need to have a much stronger response in the area of Aboriginal over‐representation in prison. We need to look at the way in which prison is used in a coercive or threatening way if we are going to keep putting it through as a deterrent effect, and criminologists know that that is not the case.

I believe it would be beneficial to remove the reference to imprisonment and put the penalty unit's equivalent in support of that principle, that we should not act by implying prison has some kind of magic value by being mentioned in the act. We should certainly be supporting the idea that the penalty should fit the crime and the offence and that it should be left up to the appropriate court determination. That is why I urge the Senate to support these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of all the Greens amendments which relate to penalties—that is, amendments 3 to 7—we will be supporting amendments 3, 6 and 7, but opposing amendments 4 and 5. The reason we are opposing amendments 4 and 5 is that, in respect of these offences, the effect of the Greens amendments is to remove any option of imprisonment, which we do not think, in respect of these particular offences, is warranted.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to amendment 3, we agree that is not a problem—penalty units rather than imprisonment. Committee members would recall that, effectively, we defined this the last time this was debated when there was some confusion about whether penalty units could in fact be interpreted as prison terms. That was quite definitively ruled out. So the effect of the Greens amendments 4 and 5 is to remove any imprisonment option, which we do not think is appropriate.

However, in respect of schedule 1, item 50, page 27, and schedule 1, item 52, page 28—and I apologise to the committee for this late notice, but the paper is being prepared now—we will be moving our own amendments which would add to the existing provisions which only provide an imprisonment penalty. They will be in respect of Greens amendment 4 to add the option of 100 penalty units in schedule 1, item 50, page 27 and amendment 5 to add 10 penalty units in schedule 1, item 52, page 28.

I apologise to the committee for this oversight, but these are in fact the same amendments that we moved in the House of Representatives to these provisions. It is not, with respect, too difficult to understand. As I say, we are supporting three of these Green amendments, but the problem with amendments 4 and 5 is that we do believe an option of imprisonment or penalty units is desirable in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what Senator Collins is saying. Amendment 5 omits `imprisonment for not more than six months' and substitutes `a fine not exceeding 25 penalty units', but amendment 4—schedule 1, item 50—omits `imprisonment for five years' and substitutes `200 penalty units'. It is my understanding, and I need to check this, that `200 penalty units'—and it does not mention the word `fine'—does not actually preclude the imprisonment option for the magistrate or the court.
—Yes, it does, with respect.

—Penalty units per se do not necessarily preclude the option of imprisonment. Section 5 says `a fine not exceeding 25 penalty units', but if you look carefully at amendment 4 it does not mention the word `fine'. It says `substitute 200 penalty units'. I believe that leaves the option open to the court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, this matter was in fact canvassed at length the last time the committee considered this issue. It was clearly stated then—and I have no difficulty, I might add, in accepting the advice as correct—that the courts do not have that option if penalty units are monetary penalties. That is it. It is not open to the court to have imprisonment.

SPEECH.PARA: If I could just explain the gravity of the offence we are talking about. I am quite happy to go to the principal act if you want me to, but that is just wasting time. We are talking about a fine of $10,000 with 100 penalty units. It is a fairly serious offence. We think it is appropriate for a court to have the option of imprisonment as well, either/or, which is why the Greens amendments are not acceptable to us. For anyone who does not understand it, 100 penalty units is a $10,000 fine.

So, to clarify, we are supporting Greens amendments 3, 6 and 7, but opposing amendments 4 and 5. I have moved my own amendments to those same schedule items of 100 penalty units in the case of your amendment 4 and 10 penalty units, which is a $1,000 fine, in the case of the schedule against your amendment 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be supporting Senator Bob Collins's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to revisit this issue, reminding myself what I said last time. We will be voting for the Greens amendments 3, 6 and 7, but we make the distinction with amendments 4 and 5 in the degree of the offence. Amendments 4 and 5 deal with, as I understand it, giving false and misleading statements on guarantees and loans, which is very different from one of the others which seeks to send somebody to gaol for simply telling somebody they could vote in an election when they could not, when they were not entitled to.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a huge difference between the degree of offence there, but we are applying a similar penalty. I think that is inappropriate. Anyway, I agree with the principle that, wherever we can, we should use imprisonment as a last resort. We will take Senator Margetts's amendments first and then we will take Senator Collins's amendments; is that right?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the committee that we proceed with amendments 3, 6 and 7? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendments 4 and 5 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Amendments (by Senator Bob Collins)—by leave—agreed to:
Schedule 1, item 50, page 27 (line 25), at the end of the penalty, add "or 100 penalty units".
Schedule 1, item 52, page 28 (line 3), at the end of subsection (3), add "or 10 penalty units".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Schedule 1, after item 43, page 21 (after line 8), insert:
Add:

(6) A report to the minister under subsection (3) in respect of the first Regional Council elections conducted after 1 July 1996 must include an examination of ways in which the representation of distinct community groups on Regional Councils could be accommodated.
This matter has already been canvassed in debate. There is no need for me to go over the ground again. Senator Kernot spoke and the minister indicated his agreement to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (lines 5 to 15), omit items 1 and 2.
(2) Schedule 1, page 7 (lines 23 to 27), page 8 (lines 1 to 32), page 9 (lines 1‐35), page 10 (lines 1‐33) and page 11 (lines 1‐16), omit item 19.
(3) Schedule 1, page 13 (lines 8‐15), omit item 30.
(4) Schedule 1, page 21 (lines 22‐29), page 22 (lines 1‐4), omit item 45.
(5) Schedule 1, page 22 (lines 5‐31), page 23 (lines 1‐34), page 24 (lines 1‐34), page 25 (lines 1‐29) and page 26 (lines 1‐5), omit item 46.

These amendments all relate to the removal of the appointment of a commission administrator and a Torres Strait administrator. I think that I have adequately canvassed why we find this to be iniquitous. The government has agreed to these amendments. As far as the opposition is concerned, they were the most offensive of the proposed changes to ATSIC and were non-negotiable in respect of any of the compromises that have been reached, not for the accommodation of the government but for the good management of ATSIC. This one was utterly non-negotiable. I am pleased that the government has agreed to support it.

I canvass again that I believe that any reasonable person—I have no doubt that this will be the view of history—who actually bothers to examine the record of this entire affair will agree that the entire package of proposals together, including special audit, freezing of funds and appointment of an administrator, was an absolutely inexcusable over‐reaction, probably poll driven, by the government in respect of an Aboriginal organisation. It was taken uniquely in respect of that organisation and not even contemplated in respect of any other organisation dispersing similar funds and having, I would respectfully suggest on the basis of audit advice, far greater problems than ATSIC has on its worst day.

There will always be problems with the accountability and disbursement of moneys in the order of $1 billion. But it should be pointed out once again that a reasonable person should also examine the breakup of that $1 billion. The minister referred to it in debate again today. It is $1 billion of public money. Fully one-third of that $1 billion goes to paying wages under CDEP. These are payments in respect of Aboriginal people who uniquely in Australia have elected to work for their social security benefits, something they do not have to do. To their enormous credit, entire communities do this.

Frankly, I think it would be very difficult to find any other isolated communities in Australia where you would get consensus on this issue to the extent you can in an Aboriginal community. Entire communities, for the community benefit, have agreed to forgo their legal entitlements under Australian law to collect unemployment benefits, which would in any case have to be dispersed by the government, and have elected to engage in community development employment programs for the benefit of the community. That is one-third of ATSIC's budget.

An additional one‐third of the budget is taken up simply with the provision of essential services such as sewerage supplies and water supplies. These are services which every other isolated community in Australia—and there are many of them—take for granted, Aboriginal or non‐Aboriginal. That is two‐thirds of the billion dollar ATSIC budget. As I have said before in respect of the quarantine that has now been imposed on that budget, it effectively removes two‐thirds of the ATSIC budget from the operations of its commission. In that sense, it effectively makes something of a shell of the organisation. I have said before, and it deserves repeating at least once more, that it effectively imposes on the commission the dirty work of imposing horrifically large cuts on the remaining one‐third of the ATSIC budget where they all fall: that is, on those programs that are absolutely essential in terms of the cultural enrichment and preservation of Aboriginal society, language and art, legal aid services and all the rest of it in Australia. It is horrendous, as far as the opposition is concerned, as is the government's entire performance on this issue.

PARA.BREAK: I am pleased that at least the government has agreed to remove this obnoxious provi sion. The reason I want to make that point is that, as significant a result as this is for ATSIC and for the Aboriginal people that it serves, it is a long way from being a satisfactory result as far as the opposition is concerned because of the entire shabby way in which the Aboriginal community of Australia and ATSIC have been treated in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support these amendments. The government claimed from the beginning that we needed this extra layer of accountability and we have disagreed with them from the beginning. I remember the original debate which set up the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. We imposed layer upon layer of accountability on that commission—required in the main by the opposition of the day—so we have a high degree of accountability on regional councils and on the regional councillors who make up the council. We have a high degree of accountability on the board of ATSIC and on the individual commissioners who comprise the board of ATSIC. We have a high degree of accountability on the chair and the deputy chair of ATSIC.

SPEECH.PARA: Added to that, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has the power to issue the general direction and he has the power to require ATSIC commissioners to show cause why they should not resign from their positions as commissioners. The whole act is structured so that there is a very high degree of consultation and cooperation required between the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and ATSIC, although it is a separate entity.

PARA.BREAK: I have always believed that this extra level that does not apply—this need for a special administrator which is not a requirement of any other comparable entity in this country—was done for the wrong reason. Senator Collins has canvassed his view of what may or may not have happened in a particular cabinet meeting and what the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) went in with and came out with. I think it is not an exaggeration to say that much of this was done in a knee‐jerk way because of misconception about public con cern over Aboriginal organisational accountability in general.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted that, as part of the cross‐party consultation that has happened on the particular bill that we are discussing, the government has been willing to withdraw this proposal. It is this proposal, on top of the general direction, which led to that wider and misinformed public debate—characterised by the maiden speech of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) last night—and this climate of misinformation about Aboriginal advantage in this country. I really regret the context of this decision which said we needed to have a special administrator appointed. The context was that out there we have Aboriginal communities and organisations who cannot handle money or who are crooks or who are bludging off the Australian taxpayer and, therefore, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has to have the right to bring in, over and above everything that we have set in place, yet another layer called the special administrator. It was ill conceived, it was politically motivated and it was the wrong thing to do. I am delighted that you are withdrawing it, and I commend you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Greens will be supporting this amendment. Obviously we have given our opinions in relation to the odious nature of the original proposal and obviously we are very pleased to be able to support it being removed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put the amendments by putting the question that items 1, 2, 19, 30, 45 and 46 stand as printed. The question is that that motion be agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave an assurance earlier about section 102 of the act, and so it will be necessary in the consequences of that that I move that item 28 of the bill be deleted. This provision would have amended section 102 of the act to prevent persons who are directors of or who have controlling interests in a body corporate that is a consultant to the commission or the Torres Strait Regional Authority from standing for election to a regional council. You will recall we discussed that earlier. The possibility that there may be a legal problem with this provision has been raised with me and I am seeking its deletion so that the issue can be properly examined without holding up passage of the bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That item 28 of the bill be deleted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition, the Democrats and the other parties in particular for the consensus that has been reached in relation to this bill. It is an example of what can be achieved in consultation. It is a win‐win situation where the government has achieved the outcome that is desired. The review that was conducted into the previous elections, as I said, will be undertaken again. I also undertake to refer the issue of the size of regional councils to the review panel I am required by the ATSIC Act to convene after each round of zone elections.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the panel will be asked to look expeditiously at measures to ensure that there is fair and balanced representation of community interests on regional councils. I would also welcome the input of the opposition parties on the appointment of the next chairman of ATSIC. I invite them and the indigenous people themselves to consult with me on the issue at the appropriate time.

So I thank the opposition, the Democrats, the Independents and the Greens for their input on this occasion and assure them that it will be my role as minister to consult as widely as possible in the interests of the indigenous people because I believe that what we have achieved today will be in their best interests. I know that I have the support of the opposition in that regard. I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I table the supplementary explanatory memoranda in relation to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table some documents.
—I will need to see them.

—One document is entitled `ATSIC 1996—The Ward System'; another one `ATSIC Regional Councils—Election 12 October 1996', produced by the Australian Electoral Commission; and another `ATSIC 1996 Regional Council Elections—Questions and Answers on the 1996 Regional Council Elections'. SPEECH.PARA: In relation to that, I ask that the minister make available the legal opinion and the basis upon which these assurances have been given to the Senate regarding the validity of the election and the decisions that the Senate is making today. The assurances have been based on some kind of legal opinion. It is extremely important that we know the basis of that legal opinion—so we know what kind of situation we have put ourselves in and, perhaps more importantly, what kind of situation we have put the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community in as a result of the decisions we have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for Senator Margetts to table the documents? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—My concern throughout this process is when many people recognise that there are problems in a system which has been imposed from above. It seems to be a system which was almost, in a way, set up to fail. It needs to have a mechanism by which people can go back and assess how it is doing. People should be assessing how it is doing if the whole system of ATSIC and ATSIC elections and ATSIC representation is meant to be serving the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it seems to me most appropriate that, if there are problems in the system, then there needs to be some way by which you go back to the people who are being affected by that system to find out what is working and what is not working and how the system can change to meet the stated functions and the real needs of those communities it is meant to be serving. This cannot be done, in my opinion, as a result of a survey at the end of every three-year election to see how the elections went.

There needs to be, in my opinion and in the opinion of a number of people I have spoken to recently, a way of finding out from those people most affected what is working and what is not working. It would seem to me to require an independent, properly funded review that can take time to go into communities and allow communities to speak for themselves, to enable the traditional operations of decision making, especially in groups that do not necessarily get represented in all decisions that are made through the current system of ATSIC operation, such as women's groups, to take place. It would seem to me to be at least a two-phase process; firstly, to work out how to put such an inquiry together and, secondly, to provide sufficient resources and time for such a process to take place.

It is my intention as a result of the debate so far not to put an amendment at this stage because that would be pre-empting what communities want and how they might want such an inquiry or review to take place. It is my intention to contact as many groups as I can in the near future to get their ideas about how such an inquiry might take place. If we are serious as a Senate in dealing with the issues of provision of services in allowing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities to move towards a greater level of self-determination, then making decisions from the top is simply compounding the problem.

I know that there are no simple answers to this but I do know that we have to spend a lot of time working out how we can go back and ask communities how they think they can have a say in how this process might be improved. It is the disempowerment that seems to be having a very great effect at the moment. As has been described to me in one particular instance, a small amount of money is provided to a group of ATSIC commissioners and they are told, `You must make a decision about where this small amount of money goes to.' So they talk, information is given, there are arguments from different groups, there is extra information and finally, through all of that process, a decision is made. Then the minister can say, `No.' That seems to be not recognised in its level of disempowerment. Many decisions are being made at the moment. A lot of them are about land issues. The disbursement of funds, the level of community participation and decision making and the level of self-determination are all very important decisions.

It seems to me that, if governments decide or even if we as a Senate decide how things should be done, we are forgetting that we should be doing our best to allow some process of real self‐determination. As I say, it is my intention to write to groups, individuals and any interested people to find out what their ideas would be about how such a process could start, how it might be put together and how it might be effective in getting ideas about how this whole process could work better. There is no doubt that there are problems but it is my contention that we should be serious about finding out how we can make it better and not simply slash and burn from above to get some cheap political capital. That is the most distressing part of this whole venture today.

It is in ATSIC's best interest, I would think, that it has the confidence of the community that it represents. Whatever review takes place, it must take those views and needs into consideration. That is what I am suggesting. It is not a comment on ATSIC. It is a comment on what I believe needs to be done for the future to make sure that ATSIC actually achieves its potential, if it is capable of doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night on the Jana Wendt Witness program an item was screened concerning the John Bertrand America's Cup research and development syndicate. The allegation was made that taxpayers had paid millions of dollars for a yacht race and that somehow I, who at the time was minister in charge of the industry portfolio, had participated in a cover‐up of this matter. I have been misrepresented previously on this matter and to my certain knowledge so has Mr Bertrand, and he may well take his own action.

PARA.BREAK: For my explanation I will give the facts of the matter. No cover‐up of any sort occurred. It is true that there was some controversy in the tax concession committee of the Industry Research and Development Board, the committee that approves syndication, and that related to the nature of the reports the syndicate had given and the timing of the arrival of those reports. It was sorted out when Price Waterhouse was appointed by the Bertrand syndicate to take care of that business for it. It then complied. The tax concession committee voted to grant recognition to the Bertrand syndicate and registered it as a proper syndi cate, and the Industry Research and Development Board endorsed that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: As to my role in this, I had none. The reason is quite obvious. The IR&D board and the tax concession committee are statutorily independent of the government and therefore of the minister. I had no role in directing their determination of any of the affairs before them. That is their obligation.

The parallel situation is that of the Treasurer and the tax commissioner. The Treasurer cannot direct the tax commissioner in the conduct of his collection of tax. In a parallel situation, at that time I could not—and absolutely rightly, in my view—direct this board to take action which could confer a monetary reward on a particular company. And I did not. If I had done—the implication of last night's program was that I should have—I would have acted improperly and ought to have been dealt with accordingly.

A further allegation in this program was that I had received a letter from the board asking me to act, and that has been repeated on a number of occasions. The fact is that I did not. The fact is that some members of the tax concession panel wrote to me asking me to take sides in an issue that the panel were dealing with. As I have said before, this is a statutorily independent body and it is entirely inappropriate for a minister to do that. And I did not do that.

The committee itself never wrote to me on this matter, and the committee itself, as I have said, fully endorsed the syndicate as an appropriate syndicate. Not only did they do that, but the tax commissioner, who in matters of taxation has the final say and does not delegate his powers, also granted the concession to this body.

A further misrepresentation concerns remarks by me that I had appointed former Commissioner of Taxation and distinguished Australian ambassador to the OECD, Mr Trevor Boucher, to chair the tax concession committee, which I had done, and Mr Boucher's resignation. The nature of the last report was to infer that he had resigned in relation to the matters that were the subject of the report—i.e. the syndicate. I am advised that Mr Boucher resigned because this government cancelled syndication, thus removing the task that he had to do. He had no purpose in fulfilling that position, and he resigned for that reason.

A further implication is that public servant Mr Alan Evans had to be shifted as a consequence of this. I am advised that the correct circumstance was that, as a consequence of a change of government, a change of structure within the department flowing from the appointment of a new secretary to the department and a downsizing of staff numbers in the department meant a transfer of some officers. That was the reason for Mr Evans's change of occupation within the department.

This is an example of misrepresentation. I would trust that the Witness program would show the same responsibility that the Seven Network has shown in its news service in ensuring that corrections to the record have been made in the news reporting, which they have to this day done. I would hope that the Witness program would follow suit and correct the record where it has misled the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this lunchtime debate to speak about an issue on which I moved a motion earlier this week with regard to the paralympians. By any measure, the Australian performance at the Atlanta Paralympic Games was an awe‐inspiring success. It even elicited superlatives from the most jaded of sports writers, and no doubt pride from many, if not all, Australians as they were enthralled and watched the enormous achievements of those people.

SPEECH.PARA: The score line of 42 gold, 37 silver and 27 bronze medals—the largest medal haul per capita of any nation in the world—cemented our status as the premier paralympic sporting nation. Medal tallies are not really a good measure of success, and they are a poor measure of the achievement of these athletes, because each one of them has overcome life‐transforming disabilities to do what they did.

BREAK.PARA: For many of them, simply learning to cope with the disabilities that they have either had from birth or have acquired through fate has been a challenge and an achievement in itself. Just overcoming the challenges of the activities of daily living is an heroic achievement on their part.

To transcend their disabilities and go further, to become athletes of international renown, is truly an awe‐inspiring feat. Our paralympians, through their performance at Atlanta, remind us of the possibilities that arise when we challenge the limitations we face in life rather than living down to them. For many of us who complain about an ache here or a pain there or that something is pretty tough, we see what tough really is when we look at what they have achieved. They also remind us that we ought to judge people by what they can do rather than by what we think they can't do.

I also want to comment on the behaviour of the paralympian athletes. Their achievements also remind us of the ethics of sporting activity. In these days when we all too frequently see in other areas of sport bad sportsmanship—we see violence, we see drug taking, we see complaints—it is worth noting that the Australian contingent at the Paralympics had no dope positives, no arrests for poor behaviour and no accusations of poor sportsmanship. We did not hear any of those sorts of comments coming out of the Paralympics that we had coming out of the Olympics themselves or other sporting activities even within our own country.

On the contrary, the newspaper reports commented on our athletes' friendliness, their cooperative attitude, even in the face of some very difficult organisational mishaps. So we should commend the paralympians not only on their performance as representatives of our nation but also on their performance in demonstrating the ethics of sport and what good sportsmanship is about. I think we can say that few countries have ever been so ably or well represented.

The Paralympics have become truly an international event. To put our athletes' performances in perspective, we should consider some facts about the scope of the Paralympic games. The Paralympic games were the world's second largest sporting event. They were bigger than the World Series, the Super Bowl and the World Cup in terms of scope, number of participants and events. Over 110 nations were represented by some 3,500 athletes with disabilities.

Australia was represented by 162 athletes, competing in track and field, swimming, cycling, basketball, rugby, shooting, goalball, lawn bowls, equestrian, powerlifting, tennis and judo, to name some of them. The competitors were elite athletes with physical, visual or mental impairments, representing four international federations—the blind, paraplegics and quadriplegics, people with cerebral palsy, amputees and others. In this context, the achievements of individual athletes stand out even more profoundly.

By including some of them I will leave some of them out, and for that I am sorry. But as a Victorian I have particular pride in the achievements of our wheelchair racers—John Lindsay and Lachlan Jones. Born with spina bifida, John Lindsay, the `wheelchair whiz', set a new world record in the 100 metres. To understand the magnitude of his achievements it is worth reflecting on a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 23 August, which states:

When John Lindsay first started racing the 100 metres, it was in a standard day chair and it took him two minutes to cover the distance. On Wednesday 21 August, the Victorian did it in 15.22 second, and won a Paralympic Gold medal.

His words on that day, when asked about his gruelling training regime and its inherent risks, were simple and profound—he said, `You get hurt, you get up, you go on.' Maybe former Senator Gareth Evans ought to take a lesson out of his book—you get hurt, you get up, you go on. He is suffering from a bit of relevance deprivation syndrome. Victorian Lachlan Jones, who has cerebral palsy, also set a world record in winning his race in the prestigious men's 100 metre wheelchair sprint.

Another highlight of the games was the achievements of Perth athlete Kingsley Bugarin. Bugarin, a visually impaired veteran of three Paralympics, had never won a medal in his chosen sport of swimming. He smashed the 12‐year‐old record of the USA's John Morgan in the men's individual medley B2 by 1.5 seconds, improving his own personal best by an incredible seven seconds. We saw parts of seconds being shaved off in the Olympics but here we see seven seconds slashed off his record. I think that ought to be noted.

Another memorable event was the win of Queenslander Brian Harvey, who has cerebral palsy, in the men's javelin. After his gold medal winning throw of 34.7 metres, Harvey was apparently disappointed with his performance. He said, `It's not good enough. It's never good enough.' That is another message that maybe we, as politicians in this place, ought to take. The message they have given us is: when you get hurt, you get up, you go on and when you have achieved you say, `It's not good enough. It's never good enough.'

Harvey's comments illustrate that the ideal of striving towards one's personal best is not an anachronism confined to manipulative advertising, as we have seen in some of the advertisements lately; it is alive and well in the paralympian team—striving to do one's best. After the commercialism of the Atlanta Olympics, I for one found it refreshing to hear that ideals of sportsmanship and achievement are still espoused by Australian athletes.

The Paralympics are a rallying point for the thousands of Australians with disabilities. Each individual achievement becomes a focus for thousands of other individual achievements. No doubt for many young people with disabilities the sorts of role models they saw in our paralympians will spur them on and give them encouragement to achieve. Hopefully each individual paralympic achievement sparks another person coping with the disability to reach beyond their limitations and to pursue a dream of representing their country in international competition.

I could go on about the achievements of Atlanta—the achievements of the Australian team co‐captain Priya Cooper, the games' most prolific medallist, winning six gold medals, a silver and bronze in the pool, or Gemma Dashwood collapsing on the pool deck after winning a silver medal in her first event. But I guess one of the finest moments occurred when the paralympians returned home and they were going through the streets of Sydney in the ticker tape parade. One could not help but be inspired by seeing Victorian basketballers Stuart and Paula Ewin—Stuart is a paraplegic and Paula is an amputee—wheeling their way up George Street with their two-year-old son James along for the ride.

In that we could see the true spirit of the Paralympics—dignity, courage and strength, combined with the active and loving support of friends, family, sponsors and all those in the community who have donated and worked to made it possible for those paralympians to achieve their goal and to represent Australia so wonderfully in Atlanta. I would like to congratulate our paralympians once again on their achievements. Like all of us, I look forward to watching them once again surpass all their goals and expectations in Sydney 2000. I am sure they will do us proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I want to return to Wanneroo, which is a great place to live, and raise a matter that I raised some three weeks ago at the same time in this chamber. At that time I predicted that the pending royal commission interim report into the city of Wanneroo would be a whitewash. I take no joy in saying that my predictions were entirely accurate. Indeed, the commission report itself has a white cover on it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not the only person who has said that it would be a whitewash. I am not the only person who has said, since the report has come down, that it is indeed a whitewash. In the West Australian on Thursday, 5 September, Dr Sandra Egger, an associate professor of law at the University of New South Wales and a member of the New South Wales Police Board, said the same thing as I said, only she used much more explicit language than I used.

I take no joy in the fact because I have seen what has happened with the corruption that has been happening in the city of Wanneroo for a long period. The corruption involves very senior officials and officers of the Liberal Party of Australia, Western Australia Branch. It has also involved Liberal Party members of parliament, some of whom remain under investigation, so I will not dwell on that or interfere with police investigations. We all know that assertions have been made by a number of individuals, some of whom have been members of my party, the Labor Party. Others who have not been members of any political party at all have also made allegations.

We know that Mr Wayne Bradshaw, once a Liberal Party candidate, has just been released from gaol. David King, a councillor from the city of Wanneroo, has also served his time in gaol and there are a few others who remain under investigation. My colleague the Liberal senator from Western Australia came into this place on 9 September and stated:

I say at the outset that the report cleared the names of the Hon. Cheryl Edwardes, the Minister for Family Services in Western Australia, and her husband . . . The findings of Royal Commissioner Davis show the allegations levelled at Mr and Mrs Edwardes to be totally unsubstantiated.
I want to read into the record the findings of Commissioner Davis, as stated in the interim report that was presented to the Western Australian parliament last week. Under 3.6.1 it states:
(a) There were audio tapes recorded by the IAU on which the voice of Mrs Cheryl Edwardes could be heard. The tapes were erased on or about 5 June 1991.
(b) No police officer holds or has ever held an audio tape on which could be heard the voice of Mrs Edwardes engaged in a discussion in which a sum of money was discussed in an improper context.
(c) The fact that Mr McLeod was acquainted with Mr and Mrs Edwardes did not create a conflict of interest nor did it influence Mr McLeod in the conduct of his investigation into Mr Wayde Smith.
Mr Smith is the Liberal MLA for the state seat of Wanneroo. The report goes on:

(d) The audio tapes recorded by the IAU in the course of its investigation into the affairs of Mr Wayde Smith, together with the monitoring sheets and most of the transcriptions, were properly erased and destroyed by Mr McLeod and members of his staff on 5 June 1991. None of the remaining transcription contains any reference to Mr or Mrs Edwardes.
I find that very strange. If you go back in the report to page 85, under 3.2.3, the report states:
At the request of Mrs Edwardes, and along with other members of the club—
the club being the Little Athletics Club at Greenwood—

Mr McLeod helped Mrs Edwardes with an election campaign which he recalls was in "the early eighties", around 1984. Some members handed out How to Vote cards but, as a police officer, Mr McLeod said he restricted himself to driving elderly voters to the polling booth.

It was very sloppy for the commissioner to record words and dates such as that. Mrs Edwardes stood first for the seat of Kingsley in the year 1988. She was elected to the parliament of Western Australia in early 1989, not the early 1980s, and most certainly and most decidedly not in 1984.

It is interesting to note that, even though Detective McLeod worked for her campaign and was investigating one of her colleagues, a member of parliament and a councillor in the city of Wanneroo, Royal Commissioner Davis dismisses it in the findings that he has brought down. Under 3.2.4, page 86, the commissioner says:

It must be kept in mind that the investigation was not into the conduct or activities of Mr and Mrs Edwardes. The target of the investigation was Mr Smith. Mr and Mrs Edwardes were no more than associates of Mr Smith. Mr McLeod made known to his superior his acquaintance with Mrs Edwardes from the outset. Further, that relationship was tenuous. Mr McLeod said

". . . it didn't concern me. I knew there was a possibility of being in a position to perhaps charge any one of the people involved with an offence of corruption and I would not have shirked from that at all."
I accept Mr McLeod's evidence and conclude that his acquaintance with Mrs Edwardes had no impact on his conduct of the investigation.
That is the case whether or not there is a record of what has gone wrong and where corruption has happened in the local authority where I live in Western Australia.

Mr McLeod admitted before the commission that he destroyed tapes on which it was alleged there were recordings of Mrs Edwardes's voice. The commissioner gave an indication of that under point 3.3.6 on page 95 of the report:

In summary, Mr McLeod said he decided in June 1991 to erase the tapes and destroy the transcripts and monitoring sheets for three reasons. First, because there was nothing on the tapes of an evidentiary value; secondly, to comply with the Listening Devices Act; and thirdly, because some of the material on the tapes and in the transcripts was, in his opinion, politically sensitive. Mr McLeod explained that "nothing of an evidentiary nature" meant to him nothing of a criminal nature. There is no doubt that evidence of the commission of an offence is all that should have been of interest to Mr McLeod. As to the second explanation, it is questionable that the tapes and transcripts should have been destroyed before the operation was terminated in October 1991.
The operation was still on the go, yet this detective destroyed evidence.
The great damage is that the commission has accepted this code of behaviour in Western Australia. The report goes on:
Evidence that may appear innocuous at one point may fit into a pattern when seen in conjunction with evidence obtained later.

I do not accept that the Listening Devices Act required the erasure of the tapes and destruction of the paperwork until the operation was completed. Mr Ayton agreed that there was no statutory requirement to erase the tapes until the operation was completed.

I said in my opening remarks that it would give me no joy to read this. It certainly gives me no joy, because what I see here is the whole make‐up of law and order—not only in my state of Western Australia, but around Australia—being completely and utterly discredited by the processes that have gone on at the Davis royal commission in Perth.

I ask honourable senators—indeed, others will do it, even if we don't—to consider for themselves the happenings in the Davis royal commission in Perth and the manner in which the commission has been conducted, and compare that with what is happening in New South Wales in the Wood royal commission. How is the Wood royal commission being conducted and how was and is the Davis royal commission conducted? I think you will find there are very stark differences indeed between them. Dr Egger, whom I quoted earlier in the article from the West Australian on Thursday, September 5, has also drawn attention to this.

There are a whole lot of other matters raised in the interim report which will undoubtedly be dealt with—perhaps in this place, perhaps in another forum. They will not be allowed to rest, or to be pushed under the carpet.

The involvement of Richard Elliott, a special adviser to the Premier of Western Australia, has again been dismissed in this report. He was at a meeting at the instigation of the police commissioner to stop certain investigation that was going on. It is all on the public record and it is contained in the report, but time does not permit me to deal with it.

In relation to the report, I also want to raise another extremely disturbing aspect. As I indicated earlier, I spoke in this place on 21 August on the matter of Wanneroo. My colleague Senator Ellison, a Liberal senator from Western Australia, came in on the adjournment speech on 22 August 1996. He refuted some of the things that I had been reported to have said in the West Australian that same day, 22 August. The matter that I want to highlight and express grave concern about is this quote from Senator Ellison. He said:

There are those in Western Australia who are simply not happy with the interim report of the royal commission which cleared Cheryl Edwardes, the Minister for Family Services, and her husband of any wrongdoing whatsoever.

I ask the Senate to take note of the dates. It was 22 August 1996 when Senator Ellison sat in this place and made that statement. I am quoting directly from the print which comes from the computer, and which is available here in Parliament House.

The interim report of the royal commission into the City of Wanneroo was actually given to the Governor of Western Australia, and it was reported in all our media, because of that, on Friday, 30 August 1996. The report did not actually become public until it was tabled in the Western Australian state parliament on Tuesday, 3 September. I made the assertion that the corruption that has occurred—and that, hopefully, has been stamped out now in Wanneroo because there have been many investigations into it—reached right to the top of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. I hope that what Senator Ellison said, in his admission to the chamber on 22 August 1996, is not an indication that it has reached right to this place, because it brings the whole matter of law and order in my state of Western Australia—indeed, throughout Australia—into complete and utter disrepute when a royal commission's findings could reach the hands of a member of parliament who is not directly connected with the royal commission.

I want to raise another matter in the short time that is available to me. It is also a matter concerning the area in which I live. The issue has been the subject of much concern, not only in Western Australia and Wanneroo, but throughout Australia. The West Australian of 5 June had a report entitled `Residents up in arms over towers'. That was referring to the Gold Coast city in Queensland.

In Western Australia, the most recent proposals to construct towers have been in the areas of Warwick, which is in the federal seat of Cowan, and Mullaloo, which is in the seat of Moore. In both instances, there were proposals to construct towers in extremely close proximity to a school or a child‐care centre. Residents, parents and P&Cs are up in arms about this, as the Gold Coast residents were, and a number of public meetings have been held and petitions completed.

I was asked by the Labor candidate for Joondalup, Dianne Guise, who is also president of the Western Australian Council for State Schools Organisations, to distribute and present to the parliament a petition calling on the Senate to:
a) immediately commence a moratorium on the erection of mobile phone towers;
b) institute, as a matter of urgency, a Senate inquiry into health and environmental risks that may be associated with mobile phone towers;

c) enact, in liaison with State and Territory Governments, appropriate legislation that shall prevent the erection of any future mobile phone towers in the immediate vicinity of any school, kindergarten, child care centre, recreation centre or playground.
I was asked to distribute the petition, which I did, and copies of the petition were tabled in this place in June and again today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Wednesday, one of Australia's most important export industries released details of a comprehensive study it had commissioned into how it can ensure its future sustainability. The sugar industry was presented with a detailed environmental audit of its operations aimed at ensuring cane farming is not only economically viable, but also environmentally sustainable. It set out to establish a benchmark of environmental performance for use in evaluating the effect of future farming practices.

SPEECH.PARA: At present the industry's economic viability is not a real concern. It has grown over the last 130 years to a point where it is now the nation's second most valuable agricultural crop, generating $2 billion of income each year. The industry is particularly valuable in my state of Queensland, where 95 per cent of the country's entire supplies are produced. Indeed, my home town of Ayr is virtually slap‐bang in the middle of the Burdekin canegrowing region, which accounts for 36 per cent of the state's sugar crop.

Although, as these impressive figures show, the industry is building on its economic success, its peak representative body—Canegrowers—recognises that the industry must be ecologically sustainable. For this reason it commissioned an independent consultant, Gutteridge Haskins & Davey, to perform this environmental audit. The audit was conducted over four months of field work. The double pronged project involved interviews with 180 industry stakeholders and the performance of 130 farm audits right along the 2,100 kilometres of the canegrowing coast of Queensland.

The audit was carried out at complete arm's length from the industry and from any pressure groups that might have been around, and in accordance with the strictest international standards. It looked at sensitive issues which need to be addressed to ensure the industry's longevity. These included air emissions, land and water management, dangerous goods and chemical usage, and fertiliser management.

There were some general findings which the consultants believe should be seriously considered by the industry. A major need was found to exist for both greater industry education of stakeholders and consultation with them. Whilst the results are obviously the bottom line, the perception of the sugar industry's environmental achievements is sadly lacking, with more than 60 per cent of the stakeholders interviewed considering growers' environmental measures in need of improvement.

The report also found that a concerted education program was needed to show farmers the benefits of adopting green practices. This would promote strategies designed to improve their individual crops without impacting on the wider off‐farm environment. The audit team found that, in general, growers would willingly do the right thing, but often did not due to lack of appropriate information.

Airborne emissions from industry practices were extensively evaluated by the report, with one of the single largest concerns raised during stakeholder interviews being that of cane firing. The seasonal burn‐offs are not only visible but also emotive, with many people—particularly those residing near farming lands—being concerned about the environmental effects of the practice and the subsequent black ash, or `snow' as it is called up our way, that firing introduces. I know that my wife and I, and other people like us who hang out the washing, are always concerned about that snow during the crushing season, although that is a pretty minor aspect of it.

But, partly in response to community pressures, growers have commenced action to reduce this problem by switching to green cane harvesting in many parts of Queensland. Since 1982, the percentage of the Queensland crop harvested green has increased by two per cent to over 40 per cent. In North Queensland as many as 83 per cent of farmers cut their cane green. The report raises the possibility that in future all of Queensland's 6,300 cane farmers might harvest their entire crops in this fashion.

BREAK.PARA: However, coming from the Burdekin, as I do, I know that, in spite of the best intentions of the industry, there are special factors that exist in some regions, particularly the Burdekin, which will preclude this. One of the hurdles is that in the Burdekin particularly, which is very flat and dry and in which, as a result, irrigation is used extensively for the crops, the foliage or trash that would be produced by green harvesting would lie in irrigation drains and would block water supply to large areas of cane. A second hurdle is caused by the sheer size of the cane crop in the Burdekin district, which is amongst the largest and the heaviest in the world. The machines used to harvest green cane are not able to do so as efficiently with the heavy crops in the Burdekin as with the smaller crops in some other areas.

Also, recently, there were some reports about Weil's disease, from rats in the cane, which has surfaced because some of the cane crops are not being fired. That is something that really has to be looked at. Canegrowers are being encouraged to look at that and also to review aerial spraying techniques, which concern communities in canegrowing areas. These days, only a few districts practise aerial spraying. The damage that used to occur in years gone by to townsfolk and to their vegetable and fruit gardens is not quite as much in evidence. There have been a lot of advances made in that area in the past few years.

The consultants also reviewed a number of concerns relating to management of farming lands, a key one being the continued expansion of farming lands. While expansion is currently economically beneficial, the audit confirmed that the desire to grow must be tempered by a balance with careful and responsible use of land. Interviews showed that conservationists believed that the government was not doing this and that it was too eager to expand beyond sustainable limits. The Queensland coalition government has announced a moratorium on expansion of one of the state's key sugar areas—the Burdekin River irrigation area. This shows that the current state government has a responsible approach to ensuring sustainable farming. It is an approach that could be looked at by other governments.

I might say that, in last night's Queensland state budget, another $23 million was provided for capital works in water in the Burdekin River irrigation area to complete some capital works that need to be done. I should also mention that I am just a fraction concerned about the approach of the previous government to the expansion of cane lands in the upper Burdekin area. To my way of thinking, it did not allow sufficient corridors and reserves for animals. That was something that the Burdekin Shire Council, more than a decade ago, when I was actually on the Burdekin Shire Council, asked the government to consider in its expansion of sugar lands. I am a little bit disappointed that there does not seem to have been enough attention paid to that particular matter.

Soil erosion and expansion on to marginal lands that are not entirely suitable for canegrowing were also tagged by the audit as potential industry problems. The consultants recommended that growers maintain a property management plan and information detailing ongoing soil changes on their properties. At present this is largely not being done.

The management of water and waste water in canegrowing activities was also causing some concern for industry stakeholders. Around 65 per cent of growers use some form of irrigation, and the consultants believed that the potential for water related environmental damage was a concern. The most significant problem appeared to be the effect of farm discharge on off‐farm waterways and associated land areas, including erosion and nutrient loading. At present there is a lack of solid data to quantify the suspected detrimental effects that unchecked emissions may have on waterways. The consultants recommended the industry establish a monitoring system of water quality in waterways and creeks to counter the negative perceptions.

Farmers' use of hazardous goods and chemicals was also tagged as an area in this environmental report. In this regard, however, the report showed that growers have displayed sound practices which minimise environmental risks. A decreasing amount of chemical solutions is being used to control pests and diseases, and growers' knowledge of their application, management and storage was found to be excellent. I know, from my conversations and from living in a canegrowing community, that farmers have for many years had a very high appreciation of the dangers of uncontrolled use of chemicals in fertiliser and in pest control. The audit team found that there was no suggestion of excessive rates of fertiliser being used. Again, I know a lot of canegrowers are trying to grow their crops using natural enhancements to canegrowing rather than the application of chemical fertilisers. Past farming practices may not have had widespread approval, but the audit did highlight that the industry was heading in the right direction.

I should stress that the audit report is simply that at this stage. At the time of the launch last Wednesday, the industry had not had the opportunity to go through the report in any detail or to challenge some of its findings.

There were some findings which did seem, at face value, to be of some concern. For example, the report said that acid soils comprised nine per cent of canegrowing land. That statement was a surprise to me. It was also a surprise to many of the canegrowers at the launch. Those findings were challenged on the spot. Of course, it is now up to the industry to look at that report, to comment on it and to move from that point.

The Queensland Canegrowers Council has given an undertaking to seriously evaluate the recommendations raised in the audit. It will no doubt be the basis for the development of an ongoing strategic plan. This will not only ensure that the environmental concerns of the broader community are met, but also keep Australian canegrowing practices amongst the best in the world.

I should say, as an aside, that it is disappointing that, at the time that the industry is doing such good work in its own backyard, the union movement—with typical disregard for the industry and all the people who are supported by it: growers, millers, the communities and the contractors—decided a couple of days ago to go out on strike tomorrow over a matter that the sugar industry can do nothing about. It is not related to the sugar industry; it is a broader industrial issue. But the union, in typical irresponsible form, is stopping the whole industry. Some 24 sugar mills, in the busiest part of the season, will be brought to a halt with a quite substantial loss of income to the industry.

I congratulate the industry on this environmental initiative. It is particularly noteworthy that the industry, of its own accord, had the courage and foresight to commission this environmental audit. It does show a display of some courage for the industry itself, without any pushing, to take on this audit.

I was very pleased to be able to lend my moral support to the industry in this far‐sighted move by attending the public launch. I was disappointed to see that there were no Democrat or Greens senators at the launch. These self‐styled champions of the environment did not seem to be present. Apparently, the environment is important to them only if it involves an attack on a Queensland industry. When an industry does something positive, of its own initiative, it apparently attracts no interest among these so‐called environmental champions.

As far as I am aware, this is an industry first. It is the first time I have been aware of a major agricultural industry taking on an environmental audit of its own volition. It is a very welcome initiative and I wholeheartedly congratulate the industry on this initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise by way of personal explanation in relation to a matter that Senator McKiernan raised a short time ago in the chamber. At the time, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are those in Western Australia who simply are not happy with the interim report of the royal commission which cleared Cheryl Edwardes, the Minister for Family Services, and her husband of any wrongdoing whatsoever.

Of course, that was a slip of the tongue, a mistake made by me. When one looks at the context in which it was said, one can readily see that that was so. I had been talking about an address that counsel had been making to the commissioner and the fact that the counsel assisting the commissioner, and the commissioner himself, were not able to defend any comments made about them because the matter was still continuing. Indeed, what I meant to have said, or should have said, at that stage was that there were those in Western Australia who simply would not be happy with an interim report of the royal commission which `would clear' Cheryl Edwardes, the Minister for Family Services, and her husband of any wrongdoing whatsoever.

It is indeed a long bow to draw to imply that I had any knowledge of what the commission's finding was going to be. If there is any implication to that effect, I reject it out of hand. That implication, indeed, would be to imply that the royal commissioner had collaborated with me, which is totally untrue. It would imply that there was, indeed, some corruption on the part of the commission and myself, which I reject entirely.
