(ac) interference with sites of significance to Aboriginal or Torres Strait people; or

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Clause 125, page 101 (after line 27), after paragraph (a), insert:

TAB.TAB: (aa) monitoring, mitigating, remedying or rectifying contraventions of section 124 regulations relating to impacts on biota or habitat; or

PARA.TAB: (ab) monitoring, mitigating, remedying or rectifying contraventions of section 124 regulations relating to interference with sites of heritage value; or

TAB.TAB: (ac) monitoring, mitigating, remedying or rectifying contraventions of section 124 regulations relating to interference with sites of significance to indigenous people; or

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 128, page 104 (lines 2 and 3), omit "124(1)(a), (b) or (c) or 125(1)(a), (b) or (c)", substitute "124(1)(a), (aa), (ab), (ac), (b) or (c) or 125(1)(a), (aa), (ab), (ac), (b) or (c)".

The major shortfall of the regulations themselves is twofold. They only cover the on‐site impact of pollution waste and noise impact other than from aircraft in flight. They do not cover the general impact of activity on habitat and biota. So if you are looking at the effect of a particular strategy, we have included biota or habitat, natural or heritage values and sites of significance to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people.

The current wording does not consider the impact of general activity, as I said, and does not consider the impact of all activities or activities that affect off‐site environments. The lessees do need to consider such general and off‐site impacts in their strategy, but government cannot draft regulations on those areas. The fact that the restriction is specific also casts doubt on the necessity of the lessee considering such impacts, since there is no explicit requirement to consider them. The requirements of the strategy also do not explicitly refer to noise impacts, so the regulations may cast doubt on their inclusion, particularly because noise was explicitly included in requirements for what must be included in the master plan and development plan.

My amendments to clause 107 would include biota, habitat and these other issues in the strategy. Clause 118 indicates that the minister must consider the noise impact. My amendment to this clause adds the need for the minister to consider impact on biota and habitat, natural or heritage values and sites of significance to indigenous people.

These amendments add to clause 124 the ability to regulate regarding biota and habitat, heritage value and areas of significance to Aboriginal people. Airport activities may impact on such things and regulations may be worthwhile, even if they are only guidelines as to what the lessee must consider and what the lessee must do in the way of examining the impact.

Clause 125 switches from prevention or minimisation of impacts to monitoring, remedying or rectifying impacts. My amendments also extend these regulations to biota and habitat, heritage and significance for indigenous people, in the same way. Whilst it might be considered that there are powers under other acts which might allow such things to occur, if the bill specifies that `the minister may make regulations on the following', it could well be argued by companies involved that regulations falling outside that in relation to airports may fall outside the purview, or it might not be a natural way of thinking by the relevant minister in terms of what is required to regulate the activity in and around airports—especially, as I said, the fact that many FAC airports around Australia include a buffer zone. Many of those buffer zones, by historical accident, include some very important areas of remnant urban bushland or even rural bushland. So it is important that there is at least the means by which this is considered to be part of what a minister can do in helping to look after the area held under a lease.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the government will not be opposing these amendments, but once again I would like to point out a drafting technicality. In amendment 19, subclause (ac) should refer to `or Torres Strait Islander people'. The word `Islander' is missing. Can I suggest a Chairman's amendment?
—Yes, that can be rectified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for any drafting errors. We were working very quickly in trying to get these amendments together, amongst other bills that we were working on. I apologise for any small drafting errors that have occurred. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Clause 128, page 103 (line 28) to page 104 (line 3), omit subclause (2) and the note.

This amendment removes the capacity of the Commonwealth to exempt airport lessees from state and territory environmental law. Commonwealth exemptions have been a problem in the past, as they are currently. We need look no further than the exemptions currently given to Telstra and Optus on stringing overhead cables or putting up towers to see this. We need look no further than the level of community concern about the proposals in the future to provide further amnesties for that to happen. The community has many concerns about this, especially as it is going further and further into the private sector.

If we wanted to look further, some of the Defence exemptions are truly worth noting. There is no good reason to exempt an airport lessee from state environmental law. The government claims that maybe the states would use an ability to set higher environmental standards than the Commonwealth does for airports to hold the Commonwealth to ransom or somehow gain a huge power. But this is something different. You are not asking for the power to ensure that the states do not make incredibly strict environmental law; you are demanding the right to exempt the airport lessees from ordinary state and territory environmental law. This is odious. I consider it is a potentially disastrous situation, based on past performance in relation to the power to exempt companies from state environmental law.

As more and more of the effects of competition policy bite, I think the community will be watching very carefully to see whether or not exemptions are passed to the private sector, whether or not the Commonwealth is really going to be able to look after the community concerns, and whether or not the normal laws of environment and planning will apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the government will very strongly oppose this amendment. This amendment by Senator Margetts could prevent the Commonwealth continuing to apply the environmental controls set out in clauses 124 and 125 to Australia's major airports on a consistent national basis.

SPEECH.PARA: It would also limit the ability of the Commonwealth to clearly identify state law which does not apply to the setting of standards, monitoring and remedying breaches of environmental standards. Once again, it is a change which will promote confusion and uncertainty. The government is seeking the opposite outcome, of course. We want certainty. We want clarity. As to the areas where the Commonwealth will regulate, it will be on airport environment matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite extraordinary, considering the amount of slashing and burning that is going on in relation to Commonwealth environmental authorities, to consider who will be left if only Commonwealth authorities enforce Commonwealth laws in the future and whether or not there will be a head of power which will allow states to take over if there is no-one left to enforce them. Perhaps the minister could advise me what will happen if we no longer have enough resources in the Commonwealth to oversee or apply Commonwealth law.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Margetts's query, I would just point out that there is no way the Commonwealth will abrogate its responsibility with regard to the environment. This is a most important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not, with a capital `N', be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might seek the indulgence of the committee. I believe I have missed out amendment 23.
—My running sheet indicates that you were going to move amendments 20 and 23 together.
—I would like to ask Senator Margetts to take these amendments separately.
—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (20) Clause 124, page 101 (after line 12), after subclause (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) For the purposes of section 128, standards and requirements set by regulations made under subsection (1) are to be regarded as minimum standards and requirements.

BREAK.PARA: We have just heard the minister say, `Wouldn't it be dreadful if we had to abide by state and federal legislation because it would mean that the Commonwealth wouldn't be able to apply its terrific whizzbang legislation and regulations and ability to monitor.' We have asked that whichever standards and requirements set under subsection (1) are regarded as minimum standards—that is, if other legislatures require greater levels or if Commonwealth legislation requires a greater level of control than is set by these regulations—it is the greater that applies. That is a reasonable thing. If in the end we have the ability to regulate down environmental standards, one would think that might create a problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of the committee, the opposition will not be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Clause 128, page 103 (line 27), at the end of subclause (1), add ", and, in particular, State and Territory laws which provide for more stringent standards than the minimum standards contained in section 124 regulations are not excluded".

I am assuming this amendment will not be passed because we have already heard that the government and the opposition believe that federal airports should be exempted from state and federal laws or standards. I have put this amendment knowing that the amendment will be lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that Senator Margetts acknowledges the commonsense of the vote. This amendment would cause great harm. It would certainly create uncertainty as to whether the Commonwealth or state controls and standards applied to particular environmental matters on airports. It would purport to require any state law which provided a more stringent standard to apply to the extent that it is capable of operating concurrently with this division of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: So Senator Margetts's amendment would have the Commonwealth set down an appropriate standard to apply on a consistent national basis to all major airports, which would then not apply in any location where a state government developed a higher standard whether the standard was appropriate to the continuing operation of the airport or not.

People employed by the Commonwealth to ensure compliance with the Commonwealth standard would do their work one day and then find that state inspectors were at the airport the next to enforce another standard and put them out of work. A person would be operating on the airport in accordance with the law one day and prosecuted the next by a different regime. I would suggest that, most likely, no-one would know what was going on, including Senator Margetts.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 185 (after line 9), after clause 234, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 234A Remedying breaches relating to this Act.

PARA.TAB: (1) Any person may take proceedings in the Federal Court to remedy or restrain a breach or threatened breach of this Act, or of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act or the Administrative Procedures made under that Act insofar as the breach or threatened breach is related to this Act.
(2) Section 221 applies to these proceedings as if the reference in that section to section 210 were a reference to this section.
(3) In this section the expression "this Act" also includes a final environment strategy, a final master plan and a major development plan.

SPEECH.PARA: The Airports Bill cannot be seen, in my opinion, as a good bill, regardless of the improvements that have been made. There is still far too much scope for abuse, high charges and, with a compliant minister or government, a lack of rigour in responding to environmental impact and ensuring they are avoided or properly managed.

We believe that there may be scope for a responsible minister to assure a decent outcome, but there is little or no scope for either the parliament, state or territory government, local government or the community to actually affect the outcome of the approval process or how the breaches of plans are handled. Yet the minister has significant powers. She or he can override state and territory environmental law. They can exempt lessees from state and territory environmental law. As we have seen, that is what they wish to do and continue to do. A local government gets no look in at all. The minister can approve any project, no matter how bad the impact or how poor that management plan. They can choose to ignore breaches of law or the agreements a company makes.

In terms of breaches of the environmental strategy, as I noted before, it is not an offence not to comply. An injunction can be sought under part 15, but only by a minister. The only recourse for the public, including state or local government, is the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That is bounded by conditions that make ministerial decisions unquestionable. They include the issuance or non-issuance of an injunction, which is the measure to be taken for non-compliance with the environmental strategy. I believe that the public, state or territory government, local government, community or environmental groups, indigenous people and so on need the right to object to what has been done. It is not right to allow untrammelled executive power.

People should have the right to take a breach or a threatened breach of this act or the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act to court. Parliament will no longer have an effective role in controlling executive power in relation to airports after this bill is passed. There must be some check on the system and the appropriate one is a judicial one.

Aggrieved parties can apply. They can currently apply under a number of acts, including the environment protection act, but the difficulty is in establishing the right to appear as an aggrieved party. We have seen various cases where it is difficult for communities to raise issues in the court because they have not been judged to be aggrieved; they have not been given standing.

Especially with environmental damage, it is difficult to approve a personal loss in regard to loss of environmental quality and even more difficult when that loss is something as abstract as the basic right of a wetlands or species to exist. How can that be considered a personal loss? How can it even be considered a loss to a local council or environmental naturalist group? We know it is, but it is difficult under law for that to be proved. It is difficult to argue and my fear is that it will not be able to be argued.

On the other hand, there are more and more opportunities for corporations to use their economic power through the legal system. We see corporations suing citizens who dare to complain about their waste being dumped into rivers. We see the current government about to reinstate measures against secondary boycotts that can and will be used against environmental and community groups organising boycotts for community reasons. We see people being stripped of their power even to take an issue to court, while those with substantial funds can take actions against individuals and voluntary community groups. This is not appropriate. It is not fair and we do not believe it is right that our amendment would allow anyone to take up a breach of this act or the EP act.

I have heard that some people wonder why we are making an exception for airports in the general measures for taking legal action on the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It is our legal advice that the other act would still contain requirements that a party must show they are aggrieved and that they have been harmed. I do not think it should be there in the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. However, this is not the place to amend that act.

I wish to establish here the fact that anyone should be able to take legal action on breach of environmental law. That is particularly important in regard to the environment. Taking legal action against the government and lessee will not be a small thing. It will be a major challenge, probably costly and time consuming and I doubt very much whether anyone would take such an action casually or mischievously. It is also a challenge that is unlikely to be taken without a reasonable chance of winning against a great imbalance of economic and political power.

We believe that anyone—an ordinary person, a community group, a group of councils or whatever—should be able to call for a remedy for a breach of this act or of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, which would protect the environment. Again, this measure would be consistent with the consumer protection measures of the Trade Practices Act. I think it is a reasonably good model to use in terms of the impact of a private sector operator on the community and things a community or sectors of the community value.

This is an inclusive measure. It allows anyone to initiate legal action if they believe there is a breach of the airports act or the environment protection act. It is not open-ended and requires an accuser to prove their case. Court action does not automatically stop a development, although the courts may issue an injunction if they believe there is a case to answer and such an injunction is justified. As with any legal challenge, an unsuccessful challenge is costly in many respects. We do not believe challenges would be made lightly.

This amendment would provide the community and other levels of government with some opportunity for redress if a minister chooses to overlook breaches of the act. That is all it does. It gives legal recourse to the community where misuse of ministerial power allows violations of law under the act. It is an element that we would like to see more broadly incorporated into law. We believe that our society would be better for it. We do this in the Airports Bill because it is before us and because the agenda of both the current and previous government has often been clearly aligned with the agenda of either the airlines or private sector rather than the wider community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate that the government is strongly opposed to this amendment. The proposed amendments seek to override judicial rulings of standing by removing any limitations on who can bring proceedings under the bill and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Normally, to bring an action for judicial review against a decision, a person must be aggrieved by that decision. The courts have taken a liberal view of persons aggrieved by a decision but have not cast the net so widely as to include every member of the public.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the proposed amendment, any person could challenge a decision about any airport covered by the bill, whether adversely affected or not. Whilst Senator Margetts openly admits that it is something she would like to put in other legislation, I do not believe it is consistent with the principles that have been enunciated. It is not in the interests of the wider community, and therefore the amendment ought not to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand Senator Margetts's concern about the difficulty of ordinary citizens in getting into court to argue a case, and I am sure there are circumstances where that has, perhaps, caused some problems. But I must say that that would be, in my view, significantly outweighed by enacting a law here that would simply overturn the question of standing which, of course, is a matter routinely addressed by judicial bodies around Australia. This may well be a matter clarified in the negative by the Acts Interpretation Act or some other act, but I was curious about the reference to any person being able to take this course of action as to whether that person would necessarily even need to be a citizen of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps if we carried this act it would be arguable that the Nebraskan chapter of Greenpeace, for example, might be able to take some action unless that was ruled out, as I say, by a definition of `person' in the Acts Interpretation Act or some other act. It would probably be arguable, at least, that you would not even need to be an Australian citizen to take this course of action. We think it casts the net far too wide and we will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of explanation, I think it is necessary to say that over time, and in very quick time, we are seeing that environmental legislation of many kinds—whether it be state or federal legislation or even local ordinances—is being overridden by the very fast march of competition policy. We see that competition policy has an overarching impact. When bodies, including Commonwealth bodies, are privatised, then much of what happens ends up in corporate law. The interests of the minor shareholders tend to override the interests of the community. It is hard to see any means by which public interest in any true sense of the word is actually being protected. In the past we had people going out from Australia—certainly from Western Australia—and saying, `We've got the world's best environmental legislation.' But if there is no way to enforce that environmental legislation, it is hardly worth the paper it is written on.

SPEECH.PARA: More and more the community are feeling that they ought to have some means of saying to government and government bodies—in this case we still have some government connection to the land in the federal airports—`If you've got these rules we should be able to require you to at least stick to them.' It seems that the environment tends to be given a short straw. Corporate laws can be enforced. As I say, the interests of minority shareholders can be enforced. Over time we will see Australian competition and consumer protection taking over regulatory functions more and more, so public interest will very much get a back seat—if any seat at all. It seems to me that, if we do not start providing this minimal protection, the environment and other human values will not get a guernsey at all.

BREAK.PARA: If this is the wrong way to put this, I look forward to the future and to perhaps being able to work with the opposition and the government to see how this might be placed in legislation so that this protection is given and that eventually we see that such things as the environment are not just things that can be overridden by every other law. If consumer protection is such that a person can have a grievance and the world has not fallen apart by persons being granted such standing, then perhaps we ought to think of similar models for the environment. As I said, if this particular model that I have suggested does not work, I would be very happy to work with either of the parties who are represented here today to see what will work.

If, in the end, we move towards the fact that corporate profit is protected and there is some weird view that competition in an imperfect market is protected but other rights are not protected and there is no redress for rules to be enforced, then we are going to be in a very sad and sick society. I will look forward to the future and seeing other proposals coming up. We will, of course, be looking at other models which we will be glad to present in the future for your combined scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not seek to unnecessarily prolong the debate, but I must say I do take some difference with Senator Margetts as to the capacity of Australian courts—or the practice of Australian courts, according to her—to make environmental laws subservient to all other laws. I would have thought that Senator Margetts could take some significant comfort from the quite recent decision of the Federal Court in the Tasmanian woodchips case: that not only do Australian courts, as Senator Tambling said, tend to place a liberal interpretation rather than a restrictive interpretation on standing, they also place some significant regard on interpreting our environmental laws in the way they are meant to be considered by parliament and do not make them subservient to other laws.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you have another amendment, Senator Margetts?
—Can I not speak?
—Do you have another amendment?
—No, but I am allowed to speak, am I not?
—Yes, but I called Senator Tambling.
—All right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was being courteous when I deferred to Senator Margetts. I think both of us are probably taking this opportunity to make some concluding remarks with regard to this legislation which has been very important in the dealing of the chamber. It is unfortunate that the legislation has taken quite some time to process and that, because of the programming of the chamber, it has had to be dealt with in such a piecemeal manner. It is indeed unfortunate that—
—The program, of course, is the government's responsibility. That is what you used to say to us.

—Depending on others who do have some intervention rules along the way. It is important to recognise that this has been a very significant debate. Of course, the legislation was subjected to very appropriate Senate committee hearings where it received wide and very thorough investigation. It is indeed a pity, I think, that Senator Margetts did not take the opportunity to canvass through that committee many of the issues that she subsequently pursued in the chamber in the committee stages in so much detail in making sure that it was considered at that time in the Senate committee. It would certainly have saved a lot of time here in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is continuing to work towards the leasing of the first airports this financial year. My colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) announced on 3 September that the tender process for the sale of leases of Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports will commence shortly. The government is, therefore, keen for the Airports Bill 1996 and the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1996 to be passed by the Senate to enable the leasing of airports to proceed. Advertisements calling for the registration of expressions of interest in these airports are expected to be published in national and international newspapers within the next fortnight.

The beginning of the airports tender process is another important step in the government's privatisation program. The tender process will be open and is expected to be highly competitive. The Minister for Finance also announced that leasing of Adelaide airport will be deferred pending the completion of a feasibility study into an integrated passenger terminal at Adelaide airport. It is envisaged that this will be completed in early 1997, after which the timing of the sale of Adelaide airport will be revisited.

The government recognises that airports are vitally important to the communities and regions which they serve. The government believes that leasing of the major airports will deliver significant benefits to airport users and industry and will enable airports to continue to develop to meet future requirements. The government expects that leasing of the airports will promote efficient airport operations in the interests of transport, tourism and trade. It should also encourage economic development of airports in ways which are responsive to the needs of users and the regions which they serve. The government will encourage airport operators to develop a partnership approach to airport operation and development. This will provide opportunities for participation by airport users as well as state and local governments, local communities and the private sector.

The cross-ownership provisions and the sales processes will establish an appropriate diversity of ownership of federal airports at the outset. Airport ownership will also be subject to ongoing scrutiny under normal trade practices controls. Of course, the airports will also be subject to restrictions on foreign and airline ownership. The government will welcome outcomes which promote the development of an export oriented Australian airport infrastructure and services industry.

BREAK.PARA: The government has made every effort to address fully the matters that interested parties, including many senators, have raised on the airport bills. Some of those concerns have been addressed in the amendments to the Airport Bill which the government has moved. The government has responded to others, including through the Senate inquiry and in both houses of the parliament.

I would like to emphasise, as I did in the Senate committee hearings, that the Airports Bill 1996 and the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1996 are very sound pieces of legislation. They have been developed over a lengthy period with the benefit of wide consultations with interested parties. They represent a considered balance between the need to have regard to the reasonable commercial interests of private airport lessees and the need to protect airport users and the community. The regulatory framework contained in the Airports Bill contains substantial protection of the public interest.

Before I conclude I would like to emphasise briefly the environmental protections included in the bill. These include requirements for airport operators to develop and implement approved environment strategies. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 will also apply. As well, the existing Commonwealth legislation, like the Endangered Species Act 1992 and the Australian Heritage Commission Act, will continue to apply at the leased airports.

As senators may be aware, the government has consulted with relevant parties on airport pricing over the past few weeks and will enter shortly into consultations on the regulations to be made under the Airports Bill on matters such as airport environment and building controls. The government recognises the interests of the states and territories in these matters and will consult closely with them. I certainly commend the bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously there has been a level of debate on this bill in the committee stage. Unfortunately, my ability to participate in the amendments is limited to the amount of time that we have and the amount of issues that we are required to deal with. I can recall that I was trying to follow the Telstra hearings as well as the industrial relations hearings during the non-sitting periods. It is extremely difficult to be in several places simultaneously. My non-appearance or even `non-efforts' to hear the inquiry by Telelink are not related to any lack of interest in the issue. Honourable senators will realise that I have followed this issue with great interest over some time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that many people in Australia still are not aware of the fact that these issues will affect them. It is not just about Sydney. It is about any FAC airport in Australia. The issues can be dealt with by the privatisation of airports. They can be dealt with by regulation. I do not think the aspects of public benefit and so on are properly protected. Nothing that has occurred with this legislation, even the improvements to the legislation, has made me feel that I should be supporting this bill to privatise Federal Airports Corporation airports.

I have never felt that creating a private monopoly is more efficient than continuing with a public monopoly. Anyone who lives in Perth would realise that there is not a great deal of choice when you want to fly to London other than Perth airport. You might be able to go from Broome but you will not go very far in terms of Europe or other places in the world. So basically somebody will be pocketing the profits rather than putting the profits back into the public entity. I fail to see how in the end we will all benefit.

But that is beside the point. There are some other issues I would like to canvass. They include some of the issues I have talked about in terms of the biota surrounding airports. It has been brought to my attention that part of the problem that has been perceived by communities is a lack of environmental management. Recently I was escorted around Perth airport by representatives from the Federal Airports Corporation. I asked some questions with regard to oil seepage that I had been advised of in an area in a marshalling yard just outside the airport. The environmental officer for the Federal Airports Corporation indicated that he had no knowledge of this.

BREAK.PARA: It occurred to me to wonder who was responsible for environmental management of buffer zones. If it was not the Federal Airports Corporation, perhaps it was the federal government, but who would be their representative on the spot to actually manage that land? You cannot expect the management to take place by people who are not there, and a day‐to‐day management or yearly management seems to be lacking in these areas. Even if there are community volunteers to assist in the management of remnant bushland or buffer zones or wetlands, they need some assistance at least to have their costs reimbursed.

Senator Campbell, at the beginning of the debate, mentioned that he recognised that Perth airport bushland was one of those areas which, although it is considered to be a significant area of remnant bushland, is in bad need of management. Even putting a fence around a piece of remnant bushland is no guarantee that that area will be managed. I would like some sort of guidance from the minister as to who is responsible for management of buffer zones, remnant bushland and wetlands, for instance, around airports and what guarantees we have that those areas will actually be managed.

If I was cynical, I might say that sometimes, when there is pressure for development, it might be easy for the lessee simply to allow an area of remnant bushland to degrade. For instance, you could allow off‐road vehicles or fires or rubbish dumping and, within a short time, you could argue that the area no longer needed care or saving or protection. What duty of care is there of lessees and, if it is not the lessees who have that duty of care, whose is it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —In her comments, Senator Margetts addressed a couple of questions to me with regard to environmental responsibilities and I am advised that the responsibility within the airport boundaries is currently with the Federal Airports Corporation, and outside that boundary it is with the state authorities. In the post‐leasing situation, within the boundary, the responsibility would rest with the Commonwealth.

—So that leads me to ask what happens in the case of, say, an area outside which might be leaking. Is it not the Commonwealth's role, or should it not be the Commonwealth's role, to take some action with the state to make sure that activities outside that area do not degrade areas inside their area of purview?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the present time, it would be a matter for the Federal Airports Corporation to address in consultation and collaboration with the state authorities and, after the leasing arrangement, it will be a matter for the Commonwealth in collaboration and cooperation with the state.

—Can I get some guidance from the minister whether there is any requirement at all for the lessees to be involved with environmental management of remnant and, if so, what kind of funding they might be required to provide, or to assist with providing. As I said, even volunteers, if they are prepared to volunteer for feral animal control or feral weed control, will need some assistance in managing the land. What sort of funding is normal? Is there any intention to require any funding to be provided for such management to take place?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there will be a certain monitoring role and that this matter will be addressed in the regulations that will be put forward.

—I thank the minister. Through you, Mr Chair, monitoring is not the same as management. Can I get your guarantee or a statement that there will, in fact, be a management as well as a monitoring role in these regulations?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —These are the issues that I did address earlier when I mentioned that they would have been much more appropriately addressed by Senator Margetts in the committee stage of the bill, where the matter was looked at in extensive detail. I must apologise to her for having to seek particular advice on these matters that do impinge on the regulation. I am advised that the regulation management and monitoring issues will be fully addressed in the future.
—That still has not addressed the issue of funding: how will management be funded?
—The Commonwealth will be responsible for the regulations, and the necessary implementation of those regulations will be funded by the Department of Transport and Regional Development.

—I wonder whether Senator Margetts could clarify for the committee precisely what she means when she talks about management. Is she talking about a Commonwealth role in managing the airport terminal and its leases?

—I thank Senator Collins for his question. I am talking about such things as the management of access by off-road vehicles, which we get in Perth airport, that can come in and rip around the area; management of fires and rubbish dumping; and management of feral animals and weed control. If there is no specific funding provided for these, even if the community were prepared to participate, then it is hard to see how that can happen. That is what I am trying to clarify. If community groups would like to be involved in helping to look after the remnant bushland surrounding airports, is it reasonable for them to expect that they can be granted funds and apply the funds to help look after these important areas?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The airport operator will have responsibility for the management of the issues, and that in turn will be appropriately monitored by the department.

—That was the reason I wanted that point clarified. I was curious to know whether Senator Margetts had anticipated a situation post-sale—I might add that Senator Margetts is free to argue that—where there would be a future Commonwealth role in the management of the airport.

—I was asked for a point of information on who would ultimately be responsible for the management—is it the Commonwealth, is it the FAC? In that case, which of those bodies would provide funding for management? Management cannot be done for no cost at all.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The FAC certainly has the current responsibility. Post leasing, the airport operator has the management and the Commonwealth the responsibility.

—I am hardly reassured, from looking at our examples of just how well the remnant bushland is being managed around Perth airport at the moment, which is not very well—you can ask Senator Campbell. If the current level of management of the FAC is passed on to a private lessee, where the community might see even less access and public accountability, then that is hardly good enough. In fact, that would mean even poorer control and management than currently exists.

—There are a couple of questions that I want guarantees on. As I said in the second reading debate, I was pleased to see that at least there was not an outright sale of the airports and that they were to be leased. I am interested in a direct answer to questions relating to the obligations of the operators of airports in respect of state and local government regulations and charges and taxes.

PARA.BREAK: Is it a fact that there will be an obligation written into each of the leases for the opera tors to meet all state and local government charges that may be decided upon from time to time? And will there be written into leases an obligation for the operator to observe all of the regulations and legislation which are, from time to time, made by state and local governments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just looking for the references to this. These issues were canvassed by Senator Harradine in detail in the Senate committees, and I was under the impression that he had received various assurances and answers at that particular time. I would draw Senator Harradine's attention to the report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee when it dealt with this bill and reported. It has been drawn to my attention that paragraph 4.16 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr White tabled a letter dated 20 November 1987 from the then Minister, Senator the Hon Gareth Evans, to the Chairman of the Federal Airports Corporation which set out the Commonwealth's policy in this area. The letter stated that:

. . . notwithstanding the Commonwealth's exemption from state taxes, it is a long standing government policy based on equity grounds to make payments equivalent to rates to local authorities in certain circumstances.
Paragraph 4.17 says:

Mr Harris concluded by advising the Committee that although the Commonwealth was unable to compel airport operators to make direct payment of rates to local government and state government authorities in the legislation, it was possible to insert requirements in the individual airport leases to require airport operators to meet the government's requirements in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely why I asked the question.

—I think the point that Senator Harradine was making—and correct me if I am wrong—is that that is precisely why he asked the question. Having laid out that scenario, is it the intention of the government that such provisions will be inserted in the leases? This a matter of great potential import, considering the amounts of money that would be involved in local councils that operate where those airports are. Is it the intention of the government to actually go ahead and insert those requirements? Will the operators of the airports, when the airports are sold, be required to pay all local taxes and charges?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to both Senator Harradine and Senator Collins, I would indicate, yes, that it is the intention of the government to proceed with these matters in leases in accordance with the enunciated federal government policy in this particular area. That has been recorded now for quite some time.

—I happen to be interested in and from memory I was involved in that committee on the airports. This is why I am pursuing these matters. I specifically asked the question today. I just want a straight answer.
—Unqualified.

—Unqualified. Will the leases contain provisions requiring the lessees to observe and to pay all state government taxes and charges as if the lessees and the airports were required to pay them now? I do not want you to say when the time comes that there is no constitutional requirement for this to be done. Clearly, there is no constitutional requirement for it to be done because it is Commonwealth territory and it will remain as Commonwealth territory. What I am trying to get from the minister—and I apologise if I cannot make it clear enough for him—is that, whilst there is no obligation because of the constitution and because it is Commonwealth territory, I want the government to guarantee right here and now whether that land will be regarded as not Commonwealth land for the purposes of state taxes and charges and local government taxes and charges.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the leases will include the continuation of the current ar rangements with regard to the payment in lieu of the charges of taxes.
—What are the current charges for which there is an ex gratia payment to the state and to the local government?

—In terms of my own patch, do the Commonwealth airports at Darwin and Alice Springs currently pay all of the normal taxes and charges that would be levied by the councils of Darwin and Alice Springs respectively?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the current arrangements extend to the ex gratia payments in lieu of rates, et cetera, in respect of the commercial interests and operations on those leases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for raising this important issue. If the public were to divest its interest in a Commonwealth airport; that is the entire airport, including the runways—and in respect of Darwin, for example, the situation would be different from Townsville and Alice Springs because Darwin is a joint facility which is used for defence purposes—and a private operator took over to run the airport as a normal commercial concern, I have no doubt that local councils would expect to treat that commercial operator in exactly the same way as any other landholder of leased land or otherwise in the council's area.

SPEECH.PARA: It not being a commercial operation of the Commonwealth of which the taxpayers are getting the benefit, as we currently are—and I might add, and I have made this point in debate before, that the Federal Airports Corporation currently is an extremely efficient operator of those airports; its landing charges and costs are among the lowest in the world for the users and at the same time operating most of them profitably—I am sure it would be the expectation of local councils, as it would in Tasmania, that if we divest ourselves as the Commonwealth of those operations then local councils would get the benefit of imposing taxes and charges on the entire operation. Perhaps you could help us all, Senator Tambling, by clarifying what the commercial operation means. Is it the terminal only or only the bits of the terminal that would be commercially operated and not the runways at all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the parliamentary secretary speaks, I might be able to help a little in this matter. In my former role as the mayor of Clarence, or the warden of Clarence as it was known in those days, I was also a member of the mayoral aviation council.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time, under the previous government, where local government areas had control over airports, the situation was a one-off situation between the Commonwealth and each airport. It was done on the basis of the best deal you could do with the local government of the day. We had the situation in Melbourne in relation to the Tullamarine airport, for instance, where the Bulla shire at one end of the airport was receiving $20,000 or $30,000 in lieu of rates. At the other end they did a much better deal with the Sunshine council, or whatever it was.

As a result of the concerns of all the mayors, including the mayor of Belmont in Western Australia and the mayor of Darwin, the mayoral aviation council got a commitment from then Senator Gareth Evans, which is what the parliamentary secretary has been referring to, that the arrangement be the same for all airports.

That particular assurance was given. It was never given for anything other than service rates, the buildings and the things you could make money out of. There were never, under any government previously—I might be wrong, but I am not aware—any rates paid on the actual runways themselves and the land owned by the Commonwealth. They were paid on sewerage, water, the value of buildings and the other things they made money out of. I think that is how it has been working.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 the corporation is subject to Commonwealth income and wholesale sales tax and state payroll tax. The FAC also makes ex gratia payments to local authorities in lieu of rates in respect of leasehold improvements on airports for which it rebills its clients. The FAC does not pay rates in respect of general airport land. While the Airports Bill does not address the issue, the operators of leased airports will be required to make payments in lieu of rates, as the FAC currently does. These obligations will be imposed by provisions in the airport leases.

SPEECH.PARA: More generally, the application of state laws imposing taxation to the airports when operated under long-term leases from the Commonwealth is unclear. The application of state taxation laws to the airports will be addressed shortly by the High Court.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tambling)—by leave—agreed to:

Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the following address-in-reply be agreed to:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY—

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.
upon which Senator Faulkner has moved by way of amendment:
That the following words be added to the address-in-reply:
", and the Senate is of the opinion that no part of Telstra should be sold."

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Bishop, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and therefore ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome my opportunity in this speech to thank the people of Western Australia for electing me to take office in this parliament. It is a privilege granted to few to participate in the public affairs of our country. That privilege imposes high responsibility and my commitment is to honour that trust and faith. I offer my congratulations to my new colleagues and wish them well in their parliamentary careers. I offer also my warm best wishes to Senator Hogg, whom I have known for more than 15 years and whom I have worked with closely in a range of forums for all of that period.

SPEECH.PARA: As is customary, I wish to acknowledge the support of the people who have provided advice or assistance in my life to date in the Labor movement. They know who they are because I thanked some of them a few weeks ago in public in Perth. It is appropriate, however, to single out one person who offered me the opportunity to work in the trade union movement many years ago. That man was Jim Maher, a former national president of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association. He also held a number of senior and influential positions in the Australian community.

In 1981 he offered me the opportunity to assume senior office in the SDA in Western Australia at a relatively young age. He guaranteed no success—simply offered a vision of the likely growth of that state and said that a job needed to be done. He offered me the chance to participate in the building of an organisation from the ground up and to be part of the dynamic growth of service industry unions in the Australian economy. As later events were to demonstrate, that was no mean offer. I thank him wholeheartedly for his support and help over the intervening period and wish him and his wife, Fran, well in their retirement.

BREAK.PARA: In my own case, I studied law at the University of Adelaide and graduated in 1981. After graduation I chose to pursue a career in the SDA, because it offered the ability to give practical expression to a number of longstanding interests. Those interests were, and are: law, economics, politics and history. Indeed, I took the opportunity to pursue some postgraduate study in economics and public policy in the United States in the years 1993 and 1994. If I had my time over, even with the benefit of 15 years hindsight, I would make the same decision again without reservation.

My family background is typical of many people who grew up in the outer suburbs of our major cities. My parents had few assets and many demands which did not shrink as their family grew to six children. Occasionally I read press or newspaper stories of the golden days of the 1950s and 1960s. Australia was apparently a land of milk and honey. I grew up in that period and have no memory of that fabled land.

Behind my family fence it was a time of insufficient earnings, mean comfort and poor to nonexistent public facilities. It was a struggle to keep family and home together. One of my clearest memories is of my mother waiting impatiently for the quarterly child endowment cheque doled out by the then government to fund purchases of school uniforms and other essential items. I do not, however, paint any extreme picture of unmitigated hardship, simply one of constant struggle.

Both my mother and father, for different reasons, placed great emphasis on the value of education, hard work and personal effort for individuals to make the most of their talents. Equally important was the expectation that individuals had an obligation to give something back to their community. Both of them were people who acted out their principles, and I know they are proud to see all of their children successful in their respective careers and professions. In particular, I have been touched at their pleasure in my election as a senator in this place.

I see the two big issues for public policy in the coming decade as reconciling the imperative for economic change and the natural desire for personal and family security. Government is the only mechanism we have that can hope to reconcile the potential for conflict between these two equally pressing imperatives and so avoid further polarisation of the Australian community. In terms of people's desire for individual and family security, the actions of the previous Labor governments in this area of family payments and family assistance packages were worthy initiatives indeed.

In this context, the policy initiative of the current government in providing tax assistance to single‐income families with dependent children is an interesting development. It seems to suggest a heightened role for the states in the provision of assistance to families and is something worthy of further study. This is because the form of the payment reflects economic recognition of the partner in a single‐income family with primary responsibility for dependent children. Personally I have no quarrel with this new direction. However, I do not think it should be at the expense of other family support programs.

I suspect this particular payment will cause much discussion in a range of circles in forthcoming years. It will be interesting to note how a government responds to the inevitable requests for its extension in future years.The soft option of cuts in other programs will not be available forever. Our side of the house well knows this because for many years we looked everywhere for the painless cut. Unfortunately, they did not exist then and they do not exist now.

The second theme I briefly wish to address is the absolute need for our economy to grow and expand in future years. A lot of the reform initiated by the former Labor government in the period 1983 to 1991 will bear rich fruit in the next few years. I suspect the productivity growth alone will surprise a lot of commentators. If those policy prescriptions had been maintained, Australians might not continue to be satisfied with achieving the modest growth outcomes of western European or Anglo-Saxon economies but might start to understand that our country has the potential to match the economic outcomes consistently delivered by our Asian neighbours over the last generation.

The previous government agenda—including micro-economic reform, the reduction in tariffs, the emphasis on growth in manufactures, and the obsession with an export orientation—were correct. I make no apology for endorsing the overdue modernisation of the Australian economy in any way.

The years in a private sector union left me with an appreciation of the dynamics of that sector in our economy. I am not aware of any superior system to that of our mixed economy. That necessarily means a continuing role for government. Generally, the mechanics of price allocation as a determinant of outcomes is satisfactory. There needs to be good reason for government intervention in the marketplace, and in no way do I advocate a return to the dreary days of yesterday's economy. My earlier comments on my own upbringing bear witness to my attitude concerning the sad state of affairs that prevailed in the 1950s and 1960s.

However, the market is not God and government has a role to play, not only in mitigating the harm occasioned by efficiency but also in stimulating industries which show clear potential for national competitive advantage in the future. In that context, our country could usefully profit from rigorous study of a number of Asian economies.

The World Bank has indeed done that study and, in 1993, concluded that the ongoing growth of east Asian economies was due to the use of both fundamentals and interventionist policies by government. By fundamentals, the World Bank said that macro-economic management was unusually good in providing a framework for private investment. It was a focus on policies that, first, encouraged high levels of savings; second, provided education policies that equipped students with the ability to enter industry; and, third, provided agricultural policies that stressed productivity—all contributed to sustained high levels of growth.

The bank, however, also conceded these policies did not tell the whole story. The bank went on to observe that in most of these economies, in one form or another, the government intervened to foster development—in some cases the development of specific industries. In saying so openly, the bank acknowledged its own violation of neo-classical theory and went on to conclude:
. . . Government intervention resulted in higher and more equal growth than otherwise would have occurred.

So according to the World Bank there is a critical role for government intervention in the development of firms, industries, sectors and markets. We on this side have never doubted the wisdom of that conclusion.

The issue of industry policy and industry development is out of favour at the moment. Instead, the government has an alternative strategy of debt reduction, balanced budgets, transparent accounting and minimal social programs. If those policies are successful in giving us full employment, low inflation, low interest rates, a balanced current account and high growth, I will be flabbergasted and delighted. I have no doubt that on their own those policies are inadequate to give the Australian economy a period of sustained economic growth of above three per cent per annum. In the final analysis, those policies will result in massive unemployment and the undoing of this government.

There is nothing inherently wrong with balanced budgets, reducing borrowings to a minimum or even transparent accounting. In most circumstances, they are desirable options. However, this government will never achieve higher and more equal growth simultaneously, because its members fail to heed part two of the advice of the World Bank concerning government intervention.

I hope to be a member of the next Labor government, which will place more emphasis on this aspect of public policy. In my time in the Senate, I intend to maintain an interest in the areas of trade and industry policy. I have also been asked to take an interest in tax and defence associated areas.

This side of the Senate is currently suffering that most terrible of punishments. That punishment is rejection. Rejection, however, can be temporary and is very different indeed from irrelevance. The next few years are times of opportunity. The opportunity to revisit our roots, the chance to plan our future and the need to develop policies that guide our country are tasks I face with relish and anticipation. I know many of my colleagues share that sentiment.

In closing, I wish to publicly acknowledge the role of my wife, Fran Marsh, and two daughters, Gabrielle, eight, and Georgia, six. The travel in this business breaks your back, particularly when most flights are of five or seven hours duration. I have been doing that travel since 1980 and, in recent years, up to 30 or 40 times a year for a range of negotiations.

One of the interesting consequences of enterprise bargaining in both national and medium sized companies is that it has centralised the negotiation process more often than not in both Melbourne and Sydney. That was an unwelcome development for those of us who lived on the western side of our continent.

The end of the week is the best time for me, as it is the time I am welcomed home and find comfort. So to Fran, I thank you for your support and our two children. Finally, I thank my colleagues for their attendance in the Senate today and I look forward to many years of robust participation in the issues that face our nation. Thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: — Hear, hear!
—Before I call Senator Eggleston, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech. Therefore I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. In rising to give my maiden speech, may I first say that I regard it as a great honour to have become a member of the Senate. I have very great respect for the place of the Senate in the Australian constitution and its role in our process of government.

BREAK.TAB: Australia is a vast and varied country with great differences between the regions, some of which, while having great economic potential, have low populations. Because of that, I believe that a system of government recognising the need for regional representation is essential for the continued develop ment and good government of this country at both state and federal levels. I was pleased that the High Court of Australia, in rejecting the recent Western Australian ALP challenge to the electoral boundaries in Western Australia, held that the concept of regional representation was implicitly recognised in the constitution as a feature of the Australian system of government, which, needless to say, in the federal sphere is provided by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also a great honour to have the opportunity of representing my own great state of Western Australia in the federal parliament and, in my case, to represent here in Canberra the north of Western Australia. The north of Western Australia makes a massive contribution to the national economy. For example, the Pilbara mining industry alone contributes 10 per cent of Australia's merchandise exports. Yet, notwithstanding this, the north of Western Australia has never had any effective representation here in Canberra, much less been represented by a person who comes from the area.

Having lived in the Pilbara for the last 22½ years, been Mayor of Port Hedland for the last three years, been chairman of the Pilbara ward of the Country Shire Councils Association, a member of the board of the Pilbara Development Commission and closely involved in the formulation of WA Liberal Party policy for the north since the early 1980s, I believe I am well qualified to give the people of the North‐West and the issues which concern them a powerful voice here in Canberra, and give the north effective input into the federal political process.
I understand that traditionally in a maiden speech one should say who one is, where one comes from in the sense of what relevant life experience one brings to the Senate, and what one's beliefs are.

I am a fourth generation Australian. My great‐grandmother, Alice Murray, was born—as Senator Abetz will be pleased to know—in Van Diemen's Land in 1839. My grandfather brought my part of the Eggleston family to the west in the 1890s. I grew up in Busselton in the south‐west of Western Australia and I went to school and university in Perth.

BREAK.PARA: I was a medical student at UWA and at that time I joined the Liberal Party and became what is now described as a `student politician', being involved in the UWA Guild Council, NUAUS as it was then known, and my national faculty bureau, the AMSA or Australian Medical Students Association. I then spent four years in the UK and, after returning to Perth, to fulfil a long‐held curiosity, I went to the North‐West—supposedly for six months, but, as is the story of so many people in the north, that six months became 22 years.

The life experiences I bring to the Senate are, most importantly, having lived in the north of this country, having been a medical GP at a time of great change in Australian medicine, having been involved in local government at a fairly senior level and serving as a member of a state regional development commission, the Pilbara Development Commission.

I would like to say a little about general practice medicine, which is undergoing something of a crisis of identity at the moment. As a recent ANU survey showed, many GPs are disillusioned and frustrated. As things have evolved over the last 25 years, the status and scope of work performed by GPs have diminished. The income of GPs has fallen, both in absolute and relative terms to that of their specialist colleagues, so that today many GPs, especially in the metropolitan areas, are genuinely struggling to meet the cost of providing the equipment necessary to enable them to give good service. Although reassuring noises are constantly made about general practice medicine remaining the cornerstone of Australian medicine, the contemporary role of the GP has never been satisfactorily defined.

If general practice is to be maintained in this country, it is important that the role of the GP within the Australian medical system should be defined and adequately funded because able and intelligent young men and women are not going to enter a discipline which does not have a definite role in the scheme of things, as well as offering job satisfaction, challenge and reasonable rewards. This is a matter which should concern the Senate because the community makes a large investment in the training of doctors.

One of the great problems of Australian medicine is that of getting medical practitioners to go to small country towns. The reasons for this are complex and not only related to working conditions but also to social factors such as education and shopping facilities and the fact that doctors' wives tend to be city girls who do not relate well to living in country towns for long periods. For some time I have thought there was an analogy to be drawn between the health and education services under which young teachers are sent out to country schools for a few years after graduation. It occurs to me that one solution to the problem of providing adequate medical services in small rural communities might be to establish community health centres in areas of need where not one, but two or three salaried doctors—to ensure reasonable duty rosters—would work as part of a team of health professionals which might include a visiting physiotherapist, occupational therapist and social worker.

I strongly support the endeavours of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, of which I am a fellow, to improve GP medicine through various means, including more effective political representation in the forums of medicine. I congratulate the college on the excellence of its innovative continuing medical education programs which are recognised world wide.

I spent eight years in local government, which I found to be an interesting experience, encompassing a wide range of activities from running an arts centre and privatising a busy airport, to dealing with tourism projects and regional development issues, as well as administering a HACC program and an aged persons' village. There is no doubt that the scope of local government is growing and, while I do not agree with the vision that some participants in the field have for the role of local government in the future in terms of local government superseding state governments, I do believe that the role local government plays in delivering services to the Australian community should have formal recognition in the constitution, as well as more secure funding.

The North‐West is that area of Western Australia roughly north of the 26th parallel encompassing the Gascoyne, Pilbara and Kimberley regions and represents about 50 per cent of the land area of Western Australia or half a million square miles. While the North‐West is a vast and ancient land, the modern north is, in many ways, a microcosm of Australia's future. By this I mean that the population is young and multicultural, there being a wide diversity of nationalities and ethnic groups, including some with close ties to Asia, not only in the old towns of Broome and Carnarvon with their Japanese and Chinese links but also in the new towns such as South Hedland where 10 per cent of the population are Malay Muslims. Furthermore, the economy of the north is export oriented and increasingly linked to the tiger economies of Asia.

As I said in my introduction, the North‐West makes a truly massive contribution to the national economy, and the great powerhouse of the north is the Pilbara. The development of the Pilbara region into one of the world's greatest mineral producing areas over the last 30 years has been a remarkable success story. The Pilbara economy is based on iron ore, natural gas, petroleum and solar salt production. The Pilbara now produces some $7 billion worth of minerals per annum generating, as I have already said, 10 per cent of Australia's merchandising exports.

Over the years, concern has been expressed that Australia was no more than a quarry for the steel mills of Asia. I am pleased to say that secondary processing is now beginning to occur. Plants are being constructed to process iron ore into hot briquettes which are the feedstock for electric arc furnaces, which is the new way steel is made. It is now quite possible that the future will see such steel mills being established in the Pilbara, which will see the fulfilment of Sir Charles Court's great plan—he once told me off, in no uncertain terms, for calling it a dream—to see steel production in the Pilbara become a reality.

Having returned today from the Pilbara conference which was held in Karratha on Monday and Tuesday, I can tell senators there are many other possibilities for large scale industrial development in the Pilbara, such as the establishment of a petrochemical industry, to mention but one.

It is educational for the Senate to know why it has taken 30 years for secondary downstream processing to begin in the Pilbara. The reasons why secondary processing is only now becoming possible are these. Firstly, it is because of the previously appalling industrial relations record in the Pilbara, which only improved when the unions came to understand in the early 1980s that the Japanese could go to Brazil as an alternative source of supply for their iron ore and that there was no question of industrial problems occurring in Brazil, for obvious reasons.

Secondly, automation has reduced the price of labour, which is a major disincentive to further development. The Pilbara 21 study of a few years ago revealed that it cost about $65,000 per annum to employ a skilled tradesperson in the Pilbara compared to about $30, 000 for the same person in Perth. While the cost of labour has not come down, automation means fewer people are employed, with a dramatic fall in the total cost of labour to industry.

Thirdly, the deregulation of the energy market in Western Australia has substantially reduced the price of energy, so that now the Pilbara offers the lowest priced gas in the South‐East Asian area. The Pilbara is now the nation's leading producer of petroleum products, the value of which was $3.77 billion in 1995.

To the north of the Pilbara is the Kimberley region. The principal drivers of economic activity in the Kimberley are the mining, tourism, agriculture, pastoral, pearling and fishing industries, with the total Kimberley economy earning the nation about $890 million per annum. Irrigated agriculture at Kununurra on the Ord River has grown rapidly in recent years, capitalising on out‐of‐season markets in Australia's southern capital cities and developing international markets. Currently, the annual production of agricultural crops in the Kimberley is valued at about $42 million, coming chiefly from the Ord River irrigation area, which is set for major expansion as another 65,000 hectares is due to be added to the irrigated area in the near future, chiefly to grow sugar, the yields of which on the Ord are much, much higher than those in Queensland.

I am delighted with the success of the Ord River scheme and salute people such as Bill Withers, Alma Petherick and Howard Young who have been there from the beginning and have been through all the trials and tribulations, because they are genuine, modern day pioneers who worked hard and endured great setbacks before they enjoyed the success that they do today.

The third region in the north‐west is the Gascoyne, which is centred on Carnarvon and extends to the eastern goldfields. In the Gascoyne, apart from the mining and pastoral industries, the seafood industry is important and provides over 60 per cent of Western Australia's prawns and scallops, with major export markets in Asia.

Tourism is the great growth industry of the north, with the icons being the Ningaloo Reef at Exmouth, the Karijini National Park in the Pilbara, and the spectacular beauty of the North Kimberley area. Broome, of course, has become a major holiday resort. The northern tourist industry is already generating about $200 million a year and the industry is only in its infancy.

Thus it can be seen that the economy of the north is not only truly massive, but it is diverse and it has come a long way from what was once the stereotype image of stockmen and cattle yards as typifying the north‐west of Western Australia.

When I first went to the north in the 1970s, the Pilbara was regarded as being marginally less remote than the far side of the moon. But that is not the case anymore. Whereas once the population of the north was transient, many people now remain in the north because they find the weather congenial, the lifestyle pleasant and the economic prospects much better than in most other areas of Australia. A generation of young people have grown up in the north who simply regard the north as home.

What I want to place on record in the Senate is that the North‐West is now simply another part of regional Australia, albeit a region which makes a very substantial contribution to the national economy, and to remind the Senate that the people of the north expect to be given due consideration when policies affecting the north are under discussion.

A good example of this not being done was the fringe benefits tax, which was designed to tax benefits paid to corporate executives in Sydney and Melbourne, but the fringe benefits tax has had a devastating impact across the whole of northern Australia. This could have been avoided if allowance had been made for differences in regional requirements, so that housing, meals, airfares and airconditioning subsidies could have been classified as necessities required to attract staff to remote areas, rather than luxuries to be taxed.

The impact of the fringe benefits tax is still being felt in terms of loss of population and restricted development in the north. There remains a need for further rationalisation of this tax. Senators may be interested to learn that the Pilbara Development Commission is currently doing a study designed to demonstrate how much revenue the federal government has lost through the cancellation of development projects in the north caused by the impact of the fringe benefits tax. When this report is completed, I assure you I will be tabling it for the record in the Senate.

Since 1982, I have attended a number of northern Australia development conferences in the north of Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. To those who attended these conferences, it was very apparent that the issues across the north were very similar. I look forward to working with my colleagues from Queensland and the Northern Territory—and I include Senator Bob Collins—in jointly pursuing the interests of the north while I am a member of the Senate.

Turning to my beliefs, senators will not be surprised to learn that I am a committed federalist. I believe that states and state governments have a valid and ongoing role in looking after the interests of regional Australia and that the federal system provides the best formula for the good government of this country. In terms of political philosophy, I am a classical liberal.
